loans.name: Adriana Del Carmen

texts.es:
With great enthusiasm and dedication, Mrs. Adriana M. has worked selling meals in the inside of the market Santa Ana in Chinandega. She began her business with a capital of C$300 (three hundred cordobas), which she invested to buy the ingredients necessary to prepare this food. For three years now she has been working with Ceprodel, obtaining loans which have greatly benefited her business, increasing her profits and allowing her to acquire greater volumes of raw materials to prepare her meals.

The need Mrs. M. is going through is the urgency to acquire ingredients to prepare the meals she sells. Because of this she trusts that Ceprodel will support her as in previous occasions. Her loan record is for 18 loans with Ceprodel.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

La venta de comida es el negocio al que con mucho entusiasmo y dedicación se ocupa la señora Adriana M. en el interior del mercado Santa Ana en Chinandega. Inició su negocio con un capital de C$ 300 (Trescientos córdobas netos) los cuales los invirtió para la compra de los ingredientes para la preparación de estos alimentos. y desde hace tres años ha trabajado con Ceprodel obteniendo créditos que han beneficiado grandemente su negocio por lo que ha aumentado sus ganancias y adquirido mayores volúmenes de materia prima para elaborar los alimentos

La necesidad que atraviesa la señora M. es la urgencia de adquirir la materia prima para elaborar los alimentos y por tal motivo confía en que Ceprodel le beneficiará como las veces anteriores. Su record crediticio actual es de 18 créditos con Ceprodel

loans.use: Investing in business, buying ingredients for food preparation (Inversión en el negocio)

loans.name: Rita

texts.es:
Mrs. Rita V. Carrion has a general store business, which through lots of effort and sacrifice, she has been able to maintain for 7 years in the city of Chinandega. The difficulty Mrs. V. is suffering is because she is a single mother and has the obligation to support her two little ones who are in school.

The need Rita is currently facing is that she does not have enough money to acquire merchandise. This is the reason Mrs. Rita has been working with CEPRODEL for 4 years, and she feels very satisfied with the loans because thanks to them she has been able to keep her business afloat and in consequence has blessed her children who need her support so much. She has a record of 20 loans.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

El negocio al que se dedica la señora Rita V. Carrion es la venta de productos varios (pulperia) que con mucho esfuerzos y grandes sacrificios ha logrado mantener desde hace 7 años en la ciudad de Chinandega. La dificultad por la que pasa la señora V. es que por ser madre soltera está en la obligación de mantener a sus dos pequeños en edad escolar.

La actual necesidad a la que se enfrenta Rita es que no cuenta con el dinero suficiente para adquirír sus productos y por esta razón doña Rita trabaja con CEPRODEL desde hace 4 años y se siente muy satisfecha con los créditos porque gracias a ellos ha logrado sacar adelante su negocio y por ende ha bendecido a sus hijos que tanto necesitan de su apoyo. Ella tiene un record de 20 créditos.

loans.use: Buying merchandise for her business (Compra de mercadería para el negocio.)

loans.name: Urania Del Carmen

texts.es:
Urania del Carmen Rodriguez V. is married and a mother of two children that are still in school. Her grocery store opened six years ago in the neighborhood of Chichigalpa in Chinandega. Urania was not able to finish her secondary studies as her economic situation forced her to abandon her studies. She felt a need to have her own income to avoid depending 100% on her husband.

Currently, her husband´s income and the income generated by her grocery store provide for her family and allow her to keep her two children in school. Mrs.Urania has been working with CEPRODEL over the past 3 years and she is very happy to have received the microloans necessary to purchase stock for her business. These loans have helped her to meet her clients expectations daily. She has received 12 microloans from CEPRODEL.

Translated from Spanish by Henry Corral, Kiva volunteer.<

loans.use: Purchase milk, sugar, rice, meat, chicken, oil, cheese, etc...

loans.name: Justino

texts.es:
Reparing bicycles is a very profitable business in Chinandega as this is the mode of transport most commonly used in the village. Mr.Justino L. picked this line of business two years ago. He began with a small investment of 7000 córdobas which he used to refurbish a small shop in the outskirts of Bisne market.

Currently Mr.Justino needs to increase the amount of stock held in spare parts since he has started selling these items as well. In the past 7 months Mr.L. has received 3 microloans from CEPRODEL which have been invested in purchasing spare parts.

Translated from Spanish by Henry Corral, Kiva volunteer.<

loans.use: Spare parts purchase

loans.name: Alejandra Marisol

texts.es:
Alejandra Q. is a hard working lady who has for the past 5 years worked selling fruits such as apple, grapes, and pears at the market of Bisne in Chinandega. Sometimes this business forces her to sell her products walking through the streets because, even though she has a section at the market, when the sales are low, she finds ways of selling in the streets of the city.

Because of her lack of resources, Mrs. Alejandra has a great need to invest in her business to increase her profits. This is the reason she has sought support from Ceprodel, obtaining loans, which she has directly invested in buying apples, grapes and pears, allowing her to support herself through her hard work day to day.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

Alejandra Q. es una dama muy trabajadora que desde hace 5 años se dedica a la venta de frutas como manzanas, uvas y peras en el mercado el Bisne de Chinandega. En ocasiones este negocio le obliga a que venda sus productos ambulante ya que a pesar de tener su tramo en el mercado, al estar bajas las ventas busca la manera de cómo vender en las calles de la ciudad.

Una gran necesidad que por mucho tiempo ha atravesado la señora Alejandra es que debido a sus bajos recursos económicos no ha logrado invertir en su negocio para percibir mas ingresos. Es por este motivo que se ha apoyado de Ceprodel, obteniendo prestamos que los ha invertido directamente en la compra de las manzanas, uvas y peras de este modo es que todos los días se gana la vida muy esforzadamente.

loans.use: Buying fruit (Compra de las frutas)

loans.name: Manuel

texts.es:
Mr. Manuel Rios works selling music and movies on DVDs. Ten years ago, he decided to invest C$ 600 (six hundred cordobas) buying these products. This investment was made through a loan from a moneylender. Manuel Rios worked very hard to pay back that debt.

It is necessary to highlight that Manuel is father to three children, and has the responsibility to offer them an education. This is why, intelligently, Manuel Rios has taken loans from Ceprodel (12 loans), which he has invested in his business, acquiring compact discs. He needs to invest more in his business to improve his and his family's quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

La venta de música y películas en dvd es el negocio al que se dedica el caballero Manuel R.. Desde hace 10 años decidió invertir C$ 600 (Seiscientos córdobas) en la compra de estos artículos, la inversión la realizó por medio de un préstamo a un prestamista. Para salir de la deuda, comenzó esforzándose grandemente hasta saldarla.

Es de mucha necesidad destacar que es padre de tres hijos con la responsabilidad de brindarle educación y por este motivo muy inteligentemente, Manuel R. ha realizado créditos en Ceprodel (12 créditos) que los ha utilizado como inversión en el negocio para la adquisición de los discos compactos. Su necesidad es invertir mas en el negocio para mejorar su nivel de vida y el de su familia.

loans.use: Buying compact discs (Compra de los discos compactos)

loans.name: Luisa Tolentina

texts.es:
Mrs. Luisa A. has worked selling lubricants for 15 years in the city of Chinandega, more specifically outside of the Bisne market in her own home. From the beginning of the business, she has worked hard to keep to support her home, and although she has no children, she is a widow, and she started the business when her husband passed away.

Very wisely she has taken loans from Ceprodel. These loans have benefited her allowing her to acquire the lubricants she sells, and in this way she has managed to improve her chances to make it and support her humble home. She currently has a record of 20 loans.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

La venta de lubricantes es el negocio que desde hace 15 años se dedica la señora Luisa A. en la ciudad de Chinandega específicamente en las afueras del mercado Bisne en su propia casa de habitación. Desde que inicio el negocio se ha esforzado para mantener su hogar y aunque a pesar que no tiene hijos, es viuda e inicia el negocio al fallecer su esposo.

Muy sabiamente ha hecho créditos con Ceprodel que le han beneficiado para la adquisición de los lubricantes y por tal motivo ha logrado mejorar sus condiciones para salir adelante y mantener su humilde hogar. Actualmente tiene un record de 20 créditos.

loans.use: Buying lubricants (Compra de los lubricantes)

loans.name: Pastora Carmen

texts.es:
Since she was very young, Pastora M. has been an excellent worker. She started working at a young age as a cleaning lady in a home of the city of Chinandega. Later, she met her husband, whom she married. Upon the birth of her children, she decided to invest in a general store, which she still has right now.

The business is located in the market of Santa Ana of Chinandega and Pastora has been keeping it stocked with new products. However, in spite of this, Mrs. Pastora is going through a difficult situation for lack of money to acquire new products. This is the reason for which she wisely approached Ceprodel to benefit herself from loans that will allow her to acquire the products she needs to continue her general store business, and in this way keep contributing to raising her children.

Translated from Spanish by Eliana Colunga, Kiva volunteer.

Pastora M. desde muy pequeña se ha caracterizado por ser una excelente trabajadora. Su actividad de trabajo comenzó desde muy jovencita como empleada domestica en un hogar de la ciudad de Chinandega. Posteriormente conoció a su esposo con quien contuvo matrimonio y al nacer sus hijos decide invertir en el negocio de pulpería que es el que tiene actualmente.

El negocio se ubica en el mercado Santa Ana de Chinandega y lo ha venido surtiendo de nuevos productos pero a pesar de esto, la señora Pastora atraviesa una situación difícil como lo es la ausencia de dinero par adquirir sus productos. Por este motivo es que muy sabiamente acude a Ceprodel para ser beneficiada con créditos que le permitan adquirir sus productos para continuar con el negocio de su pulpería y así seguir contribuyendo con la formación de sus hijos.

loans.use: Buying merchandise to sell (Compra de los productos para su venta)

loans.name: I Made Wenten

texts.id:
I Made Wenten, 50 tahun, tinggal di desa Manistutu, sebuah desa di Bali Barat yang mana hampir 90 % penduduknya bermata pencaharian sebagai petani. Khusus untuk lingkungan I Made Wenten, sebagian besar petani bercocok tanam dengan menanam padi. Hal ini disebabkan karena pengairan diwilayah tersebut mencukupi untuk menanam padi. Sebagai seorang petani, I Made Wenten paham akan kebutuhan para petani pada saat masa tanam.
Petani di desa I Made Wenten sangat membutuhkan pupuk untuk meningkatkan produktifitas sawahnya. Namun yang menjadi kendala adalah sulitnya mencari pupuk karena selain jarak pedagang pupuk yang cukup jauh, ketersediaan pupuk pun sangat minim. Melihat hal ini, I Made Wenten menganggap sebagi peluang bisnis yang bisa diandalkan. Selain tetap mengerjakan sawahnya sendiri, I Made Wenten melayani penjualan beraneka jenis pupuk yang diperlukan oleh petani. Dengan pinjaman dari Dinari, I Made Wenten membeli pupuk di pedagang besar dan memasarkannya kembali. Para petani merasa sangat terbantu dengan usaha I Made Wenten, karena mereka dapat dengan mudah memperoleh pupuk. Satu hal yang sangat dihargai oleh para petani adalah layanan antar oleh I Made Wenten kepada para pembeli. Dengan usaha ini, I Made Wenten merasa sangat terbantu dari segi perekonomiannya dan ia sangat berterima kasih atas pinjaman yang didapatnya.

loans.use: Membeli Pupuk

loans.name: Ni Made Dening

texts.id:
Ni made Dening is a woman who understands a housewife's responsibility, which is not only dependent on her husband to fulfill all her needs. She proved this attitude from her diligence in running a pigf farm specializing in breeding pigs. She has been in the business for years. She could help her husband in fulfilling the family's financial needs, especially to school her daughter, Ni Luh Purnawatu who is now in 3rd grade of Junior high school, from the business earnings. She farms a breeding pig diligently despite using only a very simple pig pen. Ni Made Dening believes that her spirit can bring her good result for her family. She earns about $275 for each pig by selling her piglets. This earnings is used to maintain her farm, like upgrading the pig pen, pay her daughter's tuition and help supplement her household needs. From DINARI's loan, Ni Made Dening hopes to expand her business, so her family's finances improves

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

Ni Made Dening adalah sosok wanita yang mengerti bagaimana menjadi seorang ibu rumah tangga yang baik, yaitu tidak hanya bisa meminta kepada suami untuk memenuhi kebutuhan rumah tangganya. Hal ini dibuktikannya lewat ketekunannya dalam menjalankan usaha beternak babi yaitu memelihara penginduk. Usaha ini sudah digelutinya bertahun-tahun lamanya sehingga dari hasil usahanya ini Ni Made Dening bisa membantu suaminya dalam memenuhi keperluan rumah tangganya, terutama untuk membiayai pendidikan anaknya yaitu Ni Luh Putu Purnawati yang masih duduk di kelas 3 Sekolah Menengah Pertama dan sebentar lagi akan menamatkan pendidikannya itu. Seekor penginduk yang dipeliharanya itu dirawatnya dengan sungguh-sungguh terutama dalam memenuhi kebutuhan pakannya. Walaupun tempat pemeliharaannya hanya seadanya tapi hal ini tidak menyurutkan semangatnya karena Ni Made Dening percaya bahwa ketekunannya akan memberikan hasil yang baik untuk kehidupan keluarganya. Dari usaha memelihara penginduk ini Ni Made Dening mendapatkan hasil Rp 2.500.000,- lewat penjualan anak-anak babinya. Hasil yang diperolehnya ini dimanfaatkan untuk mengelola usahanya termasuk mengusahakan kandang yang layak, menyekolahkan anaknya dan membantu mencukupi kebutuhan rumah tangganya. Dengan mendapat pinjaman modal dari DINARI, NI Made Dening berharap usahanya bisa dikembangkan dan kehidupan keluarganyapun semakin sejahtera.

loans.use: Purchase Breeding Pig and Feeds

loans.name: Ni Wayan Suatri

texts.id:
Being not young anymore, 42 year old, does not make Ni Wayan Suatri lazy working. Not only because of economic needs, but also her responsibility to support the future of his child who just started first grade of high school. Ni Wayan Suatri realized that her husband's farming income could not support all her family's need anymore. So she wants to help her husband in bringing in extra income by starting a small pig farm in her home. Despite only using simple pig pen, she could farm several fattening pigs to be later slaughtered. From this small business profit, Ni Wayan Suatri realized significant benefit to her family's finances. Each fattening pig, farmed for 6 months, she could earn $66 profit, and it could help pay her child's tuition and save the rest for her old days. DINARI loans was used to buy more pigs and quality feeds so her product can satisfy customer and increase her profit.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

Dalam usia yang tidak bisa dibilang muda lagi yaitu 42 tahun tidak membuat Ni Wayan Suatri menjadi malas dalam bekerja. Itu bukan saja karena tuntutan hidup, tetapi juga karena rasa tanggung jawabnya atas masa depan seorang anaknya yang masih harus ditanggungnya terutama dalam hal pendidikannya yang baru menginjak tahun pertama Sekolah menengah atas. Ni Wayan Suatri melihat bahwa penghasilan suaminya yang hanya seorang petani dengan penghasilan yang pas-pasan sudah tidak bisa lagi mencukupi keperluan keluarganya, sehingga timbul niatnya untuk membantu suaminya dalam memenuhi kebutuhan rumah tangganya yaitu dengan memelihara ternak babi di rumahnya. Walaupun kandangnya sederhana tapi itu dirasanya sudah cukup untuk bisa memelihara beberapa ekor babi khususnya babi penggemukan. Dari usaha yang digelutinya ini Ni Wayan Suatri merasakan manfaat yang luar biasa terhadap kesejahteraan keluarganya, karena selain memiliki kesibukan setiap harinya, usahanya ini juga bisa memberikan keuntungan walaupun jumlahnya tidak begitu besar. Dari satu ekor babi penggemukan yang dipelihara selama enam bulan bisa menghasilkan keuntungan sekitar Rp 600.000,- dan itu bisa dipergunakannya untuk membiayai sekolah anaknya dan sebagian kecil disimpannya untuk tabungan di hari tuanya kelak. Pinjaman yang diperolehnya dari DINARI dipergunakannya untuk menambah jumlah babi penggemukan dan juga pengadaan pakan yang berkualitas supaya hasilnya bisa memuaskan dan meningkatkan keuntungannya.

loans.use: Purchase piglets and feeds

loans.name: Ni Luh Darmi

texts.id:
Ni Luh Darmi is used to simple living. This mother of three children has learned to accept life's lessons. This attitude has helped her to raise her children and provide them with good education so they grow up responsibly. At this time, she is still responsible to school her smallest child, Komang Trisna Putra who is in 8th grade. The other children has been able to afford their living independently, even though only working as manual labor. Her love to the her family made Ni Luh Darmi tried to help her husband in supporting the family's financial needs. She decided to start fattening pigs, a business chosen by other women in her neighborhood, so she could also learn from their experiences. She does not make much profit, only about $22 to 33 for each pig slaughtered after three months fattening. However, it helped cover some household needs, from kitchen supplies, health care, and other needs. DINARI is going to help her by providing a loan for her to buy more pigs and more feeds.

Translated from Indonesian by Kresna Hartandi, Kiva Volunteer

Hidup dalam kesederhanaan sudah menjadi bagian dalam kehidupan Ni Luh Darmi. Ibu yang memiliki 3 (tiga) orang anak ini selalu belajar untuk menerima setiap hal yang dialaminya sebagai pelajarang yang berharga dalam hidupnya. Hal inilah yang membuatnya mampu membesarkan anak-anaknya dan memberikan mereka didikan yang baik sehingga mereka bisa bertumbuh menjadi anak yang patuh dan ulet. Saat ini tanggung jawabnya dalam memberikan pendidikan secara formal masih kepada anaknya yang paling kecil yaitu Komang Trisna Putra yang masih duduk di kelas dua Sekolah Menengah Pertama, sedangkan yang lainnya sudah mampu membiayai hidupnya masing-masing karena sudah bekerja walaupun hanya sebagai buruh kasar. Kecintaannya terhadap keluarga membuat hatinya tergerak untuk ikut serta mengupayakan kesejahteraan keluarganya dengan membantu suaminya untuk bisa memenuhi kebutuhan hidup yang semakin hari semakin meningkat. Jalan yang ditempuhnya adalah dengan memlihara babi penggemukan seperti yang juga digeluti oleh banyak ibu-ibu yang lainnya sehingga Ni Luh Darmi bisa belajar dari setiap keberhasilan mereka. Keuntungan yang diperolehnya memang tidak terlalu besar yaitu sekitar Rp 200.000,- Rp 300.000,- per ekor dari memelihara babi untuk babi guling yang dipelihara hanya dua atau tiga bulan saja, tetapi itu cukup bermanfaat dalam menutupi segala kekurangan biaya rumah tangganya baik itu keperluan dapur, kesehatan perumahan ataupun hal lainnya. DINARI memberinya bantuan modal usaha dan itu dipakainya untuk menambah jumlah penggemukan yang dipeliharanya dan juga untuk memenuhi kebutuhan pakan ternaknya tersebut.

loans.use: Purchase feed and piglets

loans.name: Ni Ketut Sudarmi

texts.id:
Raising pigs has long been one of the means of livelihood for rural women in Bali. For Ni Ketut Sudarmi, tending to livestock is not just about following a cultural practice. It benefits her family, especially because her efforts in this activity do not consume too much of her time and she is still able to take care of the home.

Working in this business requires perseverance and diligence because there are substantial challenges, including rising feed prices and problems with the health of the livestock.

With her children all grown up, it is only her, her husband and her two grandchildren. But this fact does not make her stop working hard because she wants to save for her and her husband's old age.

This activity of raising livestock began many years ago, but the methods were simple then. Consequently the end result was not very good; only enough to fulfill basic daily needs and allow for very modest savings. The pigs raised usually sold to businessmen who represent customers. Selling pigs to grow their income, they can get Rp. 600,000 up to Rp. 700,000 (USD equivalent $64 - $75). With assistance from DINARI in the form of capital (which was used to found this activity to begin with) Ni Ketut Sudarmi hopes that her dream of a successful business and a happy retirement can be achieved.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Aarati, Kiva volunteer.

Salah satu budaya kehidupan wanita pedesaan di Bali adalah memelihara ternak babi. Tetapi bagi Ni Ketut Sudarmi memelihara babi dilakukannya bukan hanya karena ikut-ikutan tetapi juga karena bisa memberikan hasil yang baik untuk untuk keluarganya, karena usaha ini tidak terlalu menyita banyak waktu sehingga untuk mengurus rumah tangga tetap bisa dikerjakan. Yang diperlukan adalah keuletan dan kerajinan serta ketekunan dalam menjalankan usaha ini karena tantangannya juga cukup berat seperti harga pakan yang semakin meningkat ataupun gangguan kesehatan ternaknya. Tinggal bersama dengan suami dan dua orang cucunya karena anak-anaknya semua sudah berkeluarga tidak membuatnya bermalas-malasan saja, tetapi tetap bekerja keras supaya bisa menabung untuk masa tuanya nanti. Usah ternak babi ini sudah dijalaninya bertahun- tahun lamanya tetapi dengan cara yang masih sangat sederhana. Karena dikelola dengan sederhana hasil yang diperolehnyapun tidak begitu bagus, hanya cukup untuk memenuhi kebutuhan hidup sehari-hari dan untuk menabung juga hanya dalam jumlah kecil. Babi yang dipeliharanya biasanya dijual kepada pengusaha yang merupakan pelanggannya. Dari penjualan babi untuk penggemukan keuntungan yang diperolehnya bisa mencapai Rp 600.000,- sampai dengan Rp 700.000,-. Dengan mendapat pendampingan dari DINARI baik berupa modal maupun pembinaan usaha Ni Ketut Sudarmi berharap apa yang diimpikannya yaitu usaha yang sukses dan masa tua yang bahagia, bisa diraihnya.

loans.use: To purchase seeds and feed for her livestock

loans.name: Tillojon

texts.en:
A. Tillojon is 52 years old. She and her husband, a pensioner have raised 7 children. 

Tillojon sells foodstuffs like pastries, cookies, candies, condensed milk, tea, and canned meat in the local market. Tillojon has been in this business for 27 years. Tillojon is very polite and her trading place is very popular in the market. The business generates the main income for the family. 

Tillojon requests 3 500.00 Somoni (1,025.00 US Dollars) for the term of 3 months. She is going to spend the loan to purchase more inventory.  Tillojon has proved herself as an honest and reliable client. She thanks everyone for their support and promises to pay the loan in time.

loans.use: To purchase foodstuffs  to expand the range of goods for selling

loans.name: Mukaram

texts.en:
M. Mukaram is 50 years old. She and her husband, a welder, have 4 children. The 2 eldest are already married and the youngest is only 7 years old. 

Mukaram’s husband is not earning much, which is why Mukaram made the decision to acquire some specialty that could bring income to the family. She participated in the training and now she has been her business already for 8 years. Mukaram makes embroidery of the national men's hats. She is really hard working. Mukaram gets up very early and goes to bed very late. Except when she is embroidering hats, Mukaram is selling them in the local market. Her trading place is located in the open air without any lean-to or protection from the cold. In the winter season it is very cold spending all the day being not protected from the cold wind. 

Mukaram requests 600.00 US Dollars for the term of 6 months. She wants to improve her working conditions in the market. Mukaram is planning to spend the loan on a lean-to and a metallic frame covered with canvas. Being the client of IMON since October 2005, Mukaram had shown herself as a reliable client.

loans.use: To improve business conditions.

loans.name: Khut

texts.en: Mrs. Khut M., 34, is a widow who earns about $5 a day selling corn at a busy local market. She lives with her one child and mother in Batambong province, Cambodia. Because her income is so limited, Mrs. M. is unable to save any money. But she is humbly requesting a loan that will allow her to buy a large amount of corm to sell to her customers. If she is able to do this, it will mean a big increase in her income.

loans.use: To buy a large amount of corm to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Seak

texts.en: Mr. Seak S., 43, is married with four children and works as a taxi-driver making around $5 a day. His wife works at home, caring for their children (two of whom are in school) and cooking. Mr. Seak S. hopes to use this loan to fix his taxi, which is broken and needs to be repaired.

loans.use: To repair his taxi

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Saida

texts.en:
C. Saida is 49 years old. She is married with one son. Their son is already married and his children adore their grandparents.

Saida sells women’s knitted jackets in the local market. She started her business 15 years ago. Her husband, an entrepreneur, provided the funds for start-up. Gradually Saida's business expanded. Being hard-working and polite by her nature she managed to attract the clients who are happy with her goods and services. The business generates stable income for the family.

Saida requests 600 USD for the term of 3 months. She is planning to spend the loan to purchase new knitted jackets for inventory. Saida is a repeat client for IMON. She managed all the previous loans accurately without violations. She thanks everyone for their support and promises to pay this loan in a timely manner.

loans.use: To purchase knitted jackets to sell

loans.name: Dilorom

texts.en:
A. Dilorom is a 41-year old mother of 2 school age children. Her husband is currently unemployed. 

For 12 years Dilorom has been the main bread-winner in the family. She is selling the national robes for boys and national hats for kids. Those national oriental items are very beautiful and extremely popular in Tajikistan. When there is a wedding party or other family occasion the boys are as a rule dressed robes and hats embroidered by hand. 

Dilorom requests 450.00 US Dollars in order to purchase more goods like oriental robes and national hats. She promises to pay the loan in 6 months and thanks everyone for their support.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory

loans.name: Saodat

texts.en:
R. Saodat is 44 years old. She is married with 3 children. The elder daughter is married, and two younger live with the parents.

Saodat sews and sells the national hats for women and men in the local market. She has been in this business for 5 years. Not so recently Saodat's husband has left for Russia to earn more money. For now Saodat is supporting the family by herself. 

Saodat dreams about expanding the business and generating enough income to improve living conditions for her family. For this purpose she needs 600.00 US Dollars for the term of 6 months. She is planning to purchase fabrics for sewing the national hats for men and women.

loans.use: To purchase fabric

loans.name: Nodira

texts.en:
B. Nodira is 37 years old. She is married with three children. 

To help her husband in supporting the family Nodira runs her own business. She sells jewelry. Nodira has been in this business for more than two years.  Initially she started 500.00 US Dollars in working capital. Currently her turnover capital has increased to 3000.00 US Dollars. 

Nodira requests 2 000.00 Somoni (600.00 US Dollars). She is planning to purchase new items of jewelry like earrings, rings, bracelets, and chains to expand her inventory. This is the Nodira's first loan and she promises to observe all the procedures concerning the payment of the loan.

loans.use: To purchase new items of jewelry for inventory

loans.name: Muhtor

texts.en:
D. Muhtor is 25 years old. He is married with one child.

Muhtor and his wife, who is pictured,  run a family business. Muhtor repairs the sewing machines and his wife is the seamstress sewing the national dresses. Both work at home, accepting the orders and performing their activities. The family business is quite successful and generates the stable income. 

Today Muhtor requests 2 000.00 Somoni (600.00 US Dollars) for the term of 6 months. The loan shall be spent to purchase the equipment need to repair sewing machines. This is the first loan for Muhtor and he promises to pay it in a timely manner

loans.use: To purchase of the equipment to repair a sewing machine

loans.name: Obid

texts.en:
M. Obid has just turned to 38 years. He is married with three children. 

For 12 years Obid has been running his own café. He is cooking kebabs. His café is located in the central local market.  Obid sells kebabs at the large Sunday market as well. As a rule Obid purchases about 15-20 kg of beef weekly for cooking kebabs. His wife and children help him in the café. The business generates the main income for the family.

Obid is planning to renovate the café by limewashing the walls. For this and for purchasing more meat for cooking kebab, Obid requests 200.00 US Dollars for the term of 9 months. Obid thanks everyone for support and promises to pay the loan in time.

loans.use: To purchase meat for cooking kebabs and for repair of the café

loans.name: Muhsinjon

texts.en:
M. Muhsinjon is 22 years old. 

With his mother, Muhsinjon sells kids clothing and shoes. The store is located in the central local market. Muhsinjon has been in this business already for 4 years. In order to have a wide range of goods for any taste and any wallet, Muhsinjon travels every two weeks to Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan, to purchase new goods. During his  absence his mother helps him in the market. Currently his working capital is about 1,500.00 US Dollars. 

Today Muhsinjon requests 600.00 US Dollars for the term of 9 months. He is planning to spend the loan to travel to Bishkek and purchase the clothing and shoes. This is Muhsinjon's first loan, however, he is sure he shall pay it in time.

loans.use: Purchasing of the clothing and shoes for kids for selling

loans.name: Zulfiniso

texts.en:
U. Zulfiniso is a 38 year-old loving mother of three children. Her husband is an entrepreneur. 

For more than 16 years Zulfiniso has been selling mens clothing in the local market. Thanks to the support and advice of her husband and her own good taste, Zulfiniso has the goods that meet the demands of the most hard-to-please customers. All the clothing is delivered from Bishkek, which is located in the neighboring country of Kyrgyzstan. Currently  Zulfiniso's working capital is about 5,500.00 US dollars.  The business is stable and generates considerable income to the family. 

Zulfiniso is planning the next trip to Bishkek for purchasing the clothing for men. With this purpose she requests 1000.00 US Dollars for the term of 9 months. This is Zulfinio second loan from IMON. The previous loan was paid timely and accurately.

loans.use: Purchasing of the clothing for men for enlarging the range of goods.

loans.name: Sutriyani

texts.id:
Sutriyani is a widow who lost her husband due to dengue fever and typhoid. Now, she is working along with her in-laws to support her child and provide for his future. To launch a fried chicken business she needs a loan of about Rp. 800,000 . Her hope is to bring in Rp. 60,000 each day (USD equivalent $6). She will sell in front of store premises that are not occupied during the evenings. Her one-year old child needs a lot of care and he is not currently getting this from his elders in spite of the fact that they are well-intentioned.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Aarati, Kiva Volunteer.

Sutriyani adalah janda yang ditinggal mati suaminya karena sakit demam berdarah dan tipus. Sekarang ia berusaha bersama kedua orang tuanya untuk membiayai hidup dan masa depan anaknya. Untuk memulai usaha Jual Ayam Gorengnya ini ia memerlukan modal awal sebesar Rp 800.000,00. Harapannya keuntungan dari usaha ini akan sebesar Rp 60.000,00/harinya. Dia berjualan di depan halaman toko yang pada malam harinya tidak dipakai. Anaknya yang baru berumur 1 tahun tentu membutuhkan perhatian yang tidak sedikit baik secara materi maupun kasih sayang dari orang tuanya.

loans.use: To purchase chicken for her fried chicken business

loans.name: Kitea F(Iv) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is N. Rose. She is currently in the business of running a grocery store and is requesting a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to increase her inventory stock. N. is 35 years old and a single mother of 5 children. Her children all go to school and range in age from 5 to 16. Each week, N. makes approximately UGX 35,000 in profits. With the extra profits from her loan she hopes to be able to expand her grocery business.

N. is joined in her small group by Llillian B., Agnes N., Lazia B., and M. Allen. Llillian B. is currently in the business of running a salon and is requesting a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to buy more hairdryers. Agnes N. is currently in the poultry business. She is requesting a loan of UGX 600,000 to finish the poultry house that is under construction. Lazia B. is currently in the restaurant business and is requesting a loan of UGX 300,000 to expand her restaurant. M. Allen is currently in the business of brick lying. M. is requesting a loan of UGX 600,000 to re-invest in her brick business.

loans.use: To expand the businesses

loans.name: Kitega F(V) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Resty N.. She is currently in the business of running a grocery and is requesting a loan of UGX 800,000 to increase her stock. Resty is 35 years old and she is single. She has 5 children who range in age from 5 to 18. Each week, Resty makes approximately UGX 30,000 in profits from her business. With the extra profits from her loan she hopes to be able to expand her grocery business.

Resty is joined in her small group by Hadija N., Betty S., Jenniffer Nasaka, and Aisha N.. Hadija N. is currently in the business of running a boutique and is requesting a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to buy more cosmetics and clothes to sell. Betty S. is currently in the business of dairy farming. She is requesting a loan of UGX 800,000 to buy more poultry feed. Jenniffer Nasaka currently runs a salon and is requesting a loan of UGX 100,000 to buy more salon equipment. Aisha N. is currently in the business of running a canteen. Aisha is requesting a loan of UGX 600,000 to increase her stock.

loans.use: To invest in the businesses

loans.name: Marlinah

texts.en: Marlinah, 34, is the mother of 2 children. She has a small stall at her house where she sells vegetables every day and earns about $15 a day. Her husband, H., is a public transportation driver in Bogor, West Java who earns $10 a day. She joined MBK to get a loan for her business so she could increase her income for her children's education. She is asking for a $75 loan and agrees to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Add to business capital

loans.name: Arinti

texts.en: Arinti, 58, is the mother of 1 son. Together with her husband, H. H., she runs a food stall in front of their house. From that business they can earn as much as $9 a day. Now she is asking for a loan of $100 to expand the business so she will be able to provide tuition for their children. She is a member of MBK and willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: expansion of their little food stall

loans.name: Siti

texts.en: Siti K., 34, is the mother of 2 children. She prepares fried snacks (photo: cooking materials such as spices, vegetables, etc.) and sells them in front of her house every morning. At noon she also sells them door-to-door around the villages, earning about $18 a day. Her husband, Ujang, has no job anymore so she has to work by herself to provide the family's needs. She is a member of MBK and asking for a loan of $125 to add to her business capital so she can provide tuition for her children's education. She agrees to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Add to her business capital

loans.name: Eny

texts.en: Eny, 28, is married to D. and has a daughter aged 6. She sells clothes and household goods on credit door-to-door, earning about $70 a month. She is asking for a loan of $125 to add to her business capital and as a member of MBK she agrees to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Add to her small business capital

loans.name: Juwariah

texts.en: Juwariah, 51, is the mother of 3 children and her husband, A., has no fixed job. To support her family's needs she sells snacks and groceries at her small shop in front of her house, earning up to $18 a day. She is asking for a loan of $125 to buy more goods for her shop and as a member of MBK she is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more goods for her shop

loans.name: Upper Kawuga A(2061) A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is K. Khadija. She is currently in the business of selling used clothing and is requesting a loan of UGX 800,000 to increase her inventory stock. K. is 29 years old and she is married. She has 3 children ranging in ages from 2 to 10. All three of her children go to school. Each week, K. makes approximately UGX 30,000 in profits. With the extra profits from her loan she hopes to be able to buy new cloth materials and fabrics.

K. is joined in her small group by Justine Nabbagala, Prossy N., Prossy T., and Teddy N.. Justine Nabbagala is currently in the business of tailoring and is requesting a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to purchase a new sewing machine. Prossy N. is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to add to her stock. Prossy T. is currently in the business of selling firewood. She is requesting a loan of UGX 300,000 to start a charcoal business. Teddy N. is currently in the business of selling hardware and is requesting a loan of UGX 600,000 to increase the stock in her hardware shop.

loans.use: To expand the businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Nyanama Twegatte Group

texts.en:
N. Immaculate, 40 years, is the chairperson of Nyanama Twegatte Group. She is a widow with 7 children and takes care of 3 relatives. She has been our client for 18 months and she sells typical Ugandan food - matooke (unripened bananas) - to her community. Her customers are mostly restaurants and stay-at-home mothers who come to her stall everyday for food. She has been in this business for 5 years and the loans she has been getting have really helped her stay in business.

With her part of this group loan, she plans to expand her business by selling more food stuffs like sweet potatoes and cassava. Immaculate is hardworking and committed because before the loans she was renting, but now she works from her home.

loans.use: Immaculate plans to restock her business with more food stuffs like sweet potatoes and cassava.

loans.name: Roda

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! Roda C. is 32 years old and she is married with three children. Her children are between the ages of 3 and 11 years old. In 2002 Roda established a clothing business and she now seeks a loan in order to purchase additional stocks of clothing in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA:
SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing whereby SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Specifically, when a client needs working capital, SELFINA will purchase equipment from said client, extend a loan to her, and then lease the same equipment back to her – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; therefore, financial institutions do not consider Tanzanian women to be credit-worthy because they lack tangible assets that could serve as collateral. As a result, Tanzanian women with low income receive poor financial support and meager access to basic needs and services. SELFINA thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional stocks of clothing in bulk.

loans.name: Olih

texts.en: Olih, 39, is the mother of 5 children. She has a grocery store at her house where she sells spices, eggs, salty fish, etc., earning about $18 a day. Her husband, D., is a coolie at a construction site who earns about $10 a week. She is asking for a loan of $75 to expand her business and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: expansion of her little grocery store

loans.name: Raci

texts.en: Raci, 46, is married to K. and has 2 children. She has a playstation (game) rental at her house, earning about $7 a day. Previously, she sold fried snacks but because of lack of capital she quit that business. Now she is asking for a loan of $125 to continue her food business and expand the rental business and as a member of MBK she agrees to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To continue her food business and expand their rental business

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence is married, but does not have children. She is a trained nurse and the proprietor of Mombasa Royal Medical Clinic based in Shinyalu Kakamega, Kenya. The clinic offers general curative, family planning, child welfare, and laboratory services. The locals appreciate the quality of services provided in Florence's facility. Florence is asking for a loan of US$1,200 to further expand her clinic.

loans.use: Facility expansion

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Kisumu Medical & Education Trust (K-MET) - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Santi

texts.en: Santi, 30, is the mother of 2 children. She has a small kiosk where she sells cell phone accessories and prepaid vouchers from various cellphone providers, earning about $5 a day. Her husband, U., sells vegetables at the market, earning about $20 a day. She is asking for a loan of $100 to expand her business and as a member of MBK she will repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: expansion of her cell phone accessory business

loans.name: Upper Kawuga A(2061) B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Sharon S.. She is currently in the business of running a retail shop. She is requesting a loan of UGX 400,000 to increase her stock. Sharon is 25 years old and she is married. She has 2 children who are 2 and 6. Both children go to school. Each week, Sharon makes approximately UGX 30,000 in profits from her business. With the extra profits she earns as a result of her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children

Sharon is joined in her small group by Ruth M., Joyce M., Madina N., and Janet S.. Ruth M. is currently in the business of brick lying and is requesting a loan of UGX 800,000 to re-invest in her brick business. Joyce M. currently runs a retail shop. She is requesting a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to add to her inventory stock. Madina N. is currently in the business of selling spare parts and is requesting a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to add to her business. Janet S. currently runs a commercial motorcyle business. Janet is requesting a loan of UGX 400,000 to buy another motorcycle.

loans.use: To re-invest in the businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Lilis

texts.en: Lilis, 40, is the mother of 3 children. Her husband, U., is a laborer who has only irregular income, so to support her family's needs she opened a food stall in front of her house where she sells noodles, Indonesian salad called 'gado-gado', beverages, etc., earning about $18 a day. She is a member of MBK and is asking for a loan of $125 to add to her business capital so she will be able to increase her income to provide tuition for her children. She agrees to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Add to business capital

loans.name: Aan

texts.en: Aan D., 29, is married to Roni and has 2 children. She has a small shop at her house where she sells sandals on credit, but she also goes door-to-door to sell her sandals, earning about $5 a day. She is asking for a loan of $125 to expand her business and as a member of MBK she is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: expansion of her little sandal business

loans.name: Mimin

texts.en: Mimin, 35, is married to A. and has 2 children. Every day at her house she makes nutmeg candy in various shapes and colors and also she spreads sugar on it, then she sells the candy, earning about $3 a day. She is a member of MBK and is asking for a loan of $125 to expand her business. She is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: expansion of her little candy business

loans.name: Misna

texts.id:
Misna has no misgivings about pushing a cart a distance of 10km each day with her husband. What she is doing is for the sake of their family. She and her husband began this endeavor three years ago. She loves this job. Each day starts at 6am, when they leave in search of items until 10am. The items they obtain are then immediately sorted. In the evening they continue their search between 2pm and 5pm. These items will be sorted the following day. They bring in Rp. 250,000 each week (USD equivalent $27). The results are used to pay the rent on their house and their child's tuition (he is in first grade).

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Aarati, Kiva Volunteer.

Menempuh jarak 10 km per harinya dengan mendorong gerobak bersama suaminya tidak Misna sesali. Apa yang ia lakukan demi masa depan keluarga mereka. Usaha ini sudah ia tekuni bersama suami sejak tiga tahun yang lalu. Ia sangat mencintai pekerjaannya ini. Setiap harinya mulai pukul 06.00 mereka sudah berangkat mencari barang – barang bekas sampai dengan pukul 10.00. Barang yang diperoleh langsung disortir. Pada waktu sore mulai lagi mencari pukul 14.00 sampai dengan pukul 17.00. Akan tetapi barang – barang tersebut akan disortir keesokan harinya. Mereka memperoleh keuntungan Rp 250.000,00 /minggu. Hasil tersebut dipakai untuk membiayai sewa kontrak rumah mereka, biaya pendidikan anak mereka yang masih kelas satu SD (Sekolah Dasar).

loans.use: To purchase scrap items for resale

loans.name: Upper Kawuga A(2061) C Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Madina M.. She is currently in the business of running a bridal shop. She is requesting a loan of UGX 1,500,000 to purchase more bridal garments and accessories. Madina is 40 years old and a single mother of 8 children. Her children range in age from 8 to 20. They all go to school. Each week, Madina makes approximately UGX 35,000 in profits. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay the school fees for her children.

Madina is joined in her small group by Justine S., Jennifer N., Monica S., and Bridget Z.. Justine S. is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan of UGX 400,000 to increase her stock. Jennifer Nakaferoa is currently in the business of selling matooke and is requesting a loan of UGX 500,000 to expand her business. Monica S. is currently in the poultry business. She is requesting a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to purchase more poultry feed. Bridget Z. is currently in the business of running a restaurant and is requesting a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to purchase more furniture.

loans.use: To expand the businesses

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: Furaha

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! Furaha M. is 23 years old and she is married with two children. Her children are 9 months old and 4 years old, respectively, and she has one other dependent, her stepdaughter. In 2002 Furaha established a crop-selling business and she now seeks a loan in order to purchase additional stock in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA:
SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing whereby SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Specifically, when a client needs working capital, SELFINA will purchase equipment from said client, extend a loan to her, and then lease the same equipment back to her – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; therefore, financial institutions do not consider Tanzanian women to be credit-worthy because they lack tangible assets that could serve as collateral. As a result, Tanzanian women with low income receive poor financial support and meager access to basic needs and services. SELFINA thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock in bulk.

loans.name: Titin

texts.en: Titin, 46, is married to S. and has 3 children. To support her family's needs, she sells spices and puts them for sale at the shop nearby, earning about $5 a day. She also sells clothing on credit and can earn as much as $30 a week from this business. To add to her business capital, she is asking for a loan of $125 and as a member of MBK she is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Add to her business capital

loans.name: Siti

Now Siti is asking for a loan of $125 to buy more inventory for her store and as a member of MBK she will repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: To buy more inventory for her store

loans.name: Uun

texts.en: Uun, 39, is the mother of 4 children and she has a small shop where she sells snacks, etc., earning about $7 a day. Her husband, U., works at a construction site as a coolie and earns a very small income. She is asking for a loan of $125 to expand her business and as a member of MBK she is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: expansion of her little snack shop

The group leader of this small group is Allen K.. She is currently in the poultry business and is requesting a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to buy more layer chicks. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

Allen is joined in her small group by Justine N., Alice K., Regina N., and Norah Z.. Justine N. is currently in the business of running a retail shop and is requesting a loan of UGX 500,000 to increase her inventory. Alice K. is currently in the retail business as well. She is requesting a loan of UGX 600,000 to add to her stock. Regina N. is currently in the business of running a medical clinic and drug shop. Regina is requesting a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to purchase more drugs to sell. Norah Z. is currently in the battery charging business. She is requesting a loan of UGX 800,000 to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand the businesses

loans.name: Kusumawati

texts.en: Kusumawati, 48, is married to J. and has 2 children. She has a small kiosk where she sells prepaid vouchers for cell phones from various providers, earning about $15 a day. She also sells snacks there and earns about $5 a day. She is a member of MBK and is asking for a loan of $100 to add her business capital. She will repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Add to her business capital

loans.name: Tatu

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! Tatu M. is 45 years old and she is married with five children. In 2005 Tatu established a general store and now seeks a loan in order to purchase additional stock in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA:
SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing whereby SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Specifically, when a client needs working capital, SELFINA will purchase equipment from said client, extend a loan to her, and then lease the same equipment back to her – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets; therefore, financial institutions do not consider Tanzanian women to be credit-worthy because they lack tangible assets that could serve as collateral. As a result, Tanzanian women with low income receive poor financial support and meager access to basic needs and services. SELFINA thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock in bulk.

loans.name: Amah

texts.en: Amah, 52, is married to A., and has 3 children aged 20, 18, 16. She sells clothes and sheets door-to-door around the villages, earning $15 a week. She is asking for a loan of $75 to expand her business. She is a member of MBK and is willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Nurhasanah

texts.en: Nurhasanah, 36 is married to N. and has 2 children. She sells clothing and household goods such as sheets, pyjamas, bulp, rice cooker, etc. on credit door-to-door around the villages. She makes $7 a day. She is a member of MBK and asking for a loan of $75 to add her business capital to increase her income to pay for her children's education. She will repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Add to her business capital

loans.name: Upper Kawugab(2061) A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Yunia S.. She is currently in the poultry business and is requesting a loan of UGX 800,000 to buy more layer chicks. Yunia is 40 years old and is married with 4 children. Her children range in age from 9 to 18 and they are all in school. Each week, Yunia makes approximately UGX 35,000 in profits. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children and re-invest in her food business.

Yunia is joined in her small group by Suzan N., Florence N., Margret N., and Milly K.. Suzan N. is currently in the business of clothing sales and is requesting a loan of UGX 800,000 to purchase more clothes to sell. Florence N. is currently in the business of running a canteen and is requesting a loan of UGX 500,000 to add to her stock. Margret N. is currently in the business of selling matooke and is requesting a loan of UGX 200,000 to purchase more food to sell. Milly K. is currently in the business of running a hotel. She is requesting a loan of UGX 700,000 to expand her hotel business.

loans.use: To invest in the businesses

loans.name: Supenti

texts.en: Supenti, 24, is married to I. and has a daughter who's 2. She has a small food stall at her house where she sells snacks, ice, candies, crispy chips, etc. She makes $7 a day with a small profit. She joined MBK so she could expand her business and now she is asking for a loan of $100 and willing to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Rini

texts.id:
Rini has chosen to focus on selling scrap items, daily work that pays weekly dividends. During this rainy season her business has been thriving; because her house is located near a river, it means she does not have to go far in search of scrap items. The elevated water level of the river brings with it a lot of items that she can recover to sell as part of her business. She uses her weekly income of Rp. 350,000 (USD equivalent $38) for her child's education as well as daily necessities. She is involved in this business along with her husband.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Aarati, Kiva Volunteer.

Rini memilih menekuni usaha Jual Barang Bekas karena ia bekerja setiap hari dengan penghasilan mingguan. Pada musim penghujan ini ia memperoleh banyak keuntungan sehubungan dengan pekerjaannya. Rumah dimana dia tinggal dekat dengan sungai. Hal ini membuat dia tidak perlu jauh – jauh untuk mencari barang – barang bekas. Permukaan air sungai yang naik membawa sejumlah besar sampah yang masih bisa ia kumpulkan untuk usahanya ini. Keuntungan sebesar Rp 350.000,00/ minggu ia pakai untuk biaya pendidikan anaknya Rp 300.000,00/bulan dan keperluan biaya hidup sehari – hari. Ia menekuni usaha ini bersama dengan suaminya.

loans.use: To purchase scrap and sundry items for resale

texts.en: Satnah, 48, is married to D. and has 5 children. She has a small shop in front of her house where she sells snacks, groceries, etc. She makes $15 a day. Since joined MBK her shop has grown. She is asking for a loan of $125 to add her business capital so she can increase her income to pay for her children's education. She agrees to repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Add to her business capital

loans.name: Upper Kawugab(2061) B Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Ruth L.. She is currently in the business of raising and selling poultry and is requesting a loan of UGX 1,000,000 to expand her poultry business. Ruth is 30 years old and is married with 7 children. Her children range in age from 3 to 12 and they all go to school. Each week, Ruth makes approximately UGX 35,000 in profits from her business. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children and re-invest in her food business.

Ruth is joined in her small group by Joyce Nakitenda, Jane K., Safina T., and Justine K.. Joyce Nakitenda is currently in the business of selling matooke and is requesting a loan of UGX 250,000 to re-invest in the business. Jane K. is currently in the business of raising and selling poultry and is requesting a loan of UGX 250,000 to start a piggery business. Safina T. is currently in the poultry business and is requesting a loan of UGX 700,000 to construct a new poultry house. Justine K. is currently in the poultry business as well and is requesting a loan of UGX 600,000 to buy a plastic water tank.

loans.use: To re-invest in the businesses

She is a member of MBK and asking for a loan of $100 to expand her business so she can increase her income to pay for her children's education. She will repay this loan within a period of 12 months.

loans.use: Business expansion

loans.name: Emelda

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! Emelda M. is a 55-year-old widow with five children. Her children are between the ages of 18 and 34 years old. In 2000 Emelda established a restaurant, and now seeks a loan in order to purchase additional ingredients and kitchen utensils. Emelda explains that when you see a SELFINA entrepreneur whose business title is "restaurant" or "café," you may have to adjust your mental image of what that is. A local restaurant or café in Tanzania usually consists of a rough wooden table and some long, wooden benches, with the sky as the ceiling. Such places don’t even appear in the Lonely Planet’s budget guide, but if you’re looking for a cheap and tasty meal, and someone to have a chat with, this is the place to be. The food is all local: rice, ugali (a hot, sticky dough, made from maize flour), plantain (a cooked, savory banana), all served with beans, vegetables, meat, and a variety of yummy sauces. Emelda thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA:
SELFINA is engaged in the economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facilities as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women. SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through micro-leasing whereby SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. As a result, Tanzanian women with low income receive poor financial support and meager access to basic needs and services. SELFINA thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase additional ingredients and kitchen utensils.

loans.name: Warni

texts.en: Warni, 34, is the mother of 2 children and has a food stall where she sells noodles, meatballs, fried snacks, coffee, etc.  She makes $10 a day. loans.use: Add to her business capital

loans.name: Nanik

texts.id:
In partnership with her husband, Nanik works to sell scrap items. In this effort, due to their ages, her husband goes in search of items, while she picks out saleable items out of what has been collected. Their five-year old child is the source of motivation for their work ethic and their energetic spirit. The money they will receive will be used to increase their sales which have been as much as Rp. 400,000 per week (USD equivalent $43).

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Aarati, Kiva Volunteer.

Bekerjasama dengan suaminya, Nanik menekuni usaha Jual Barang Bekas. Dalam menjalani usaha ini - karena faktor usia – suaminya yang berkeliling mencari barang – barang bekas, sedangkan dirinya bagian yang menyeleksi barang – barang yang telah diperoleh tersebut. Anak mereka - yang berusia 5 tahun - yang menjadi tanggungan mereka memacu semangat mereka untuk lebih lagi bekerja lebih giat. Modal usaha yang dia terima akan ia gunakan untuk meningkatkan penghasilannya yang sebelumnya sebesar Rp 400.000,00/minggu.

loans.use: To purchase assorted scrap items for resale

loans.name: Boeung

texts.en: Mrs. Boeung S., 25, is married with two young children. She helps support her family by running a stand at a busy market where she makes about $10 a day selling pork, beef and chicken. Her husband breeds the pigs which his wife sells at her stand. Mrs. Boeung S. plans to use this loan to buy piglets, which she and her husband will raise and later sell at her stand, where demand for pork is high.

loans.use: To purchase more pigs to meet her client's demand.

loans.name: Sim

texts.en: Mrs. Sim S., 31, is married with two children and lives with her husband in Batambong province, Cambodia. She works selling various kinds of snacks at a busy market and typically earns around $5 a day. Her husband is self-employed as a construction foreman and a farmer who grows rice. He makes around $7 a day. Mrs. S. hopes to use this loan to buy a small hand-tractor for her husband to use when plowing the soil on their farm.

loans.use: To purchase a small hand-tractor for her husband to use when plowing the soil on their farm.

payments.comment:
Congratulations! Your Kiva loan has been paid back ahead of time.

Thanks to your support of entrepreneurs like Sim Samoeun, small businesses around the world have access to low-interest loans to help their business.

We hope you will continue loaning through Kiva and CREDIT MFI.

Best regards,
Isadora Tang
Kiva Fellow,
Cambodia

loans.name: Akutwala Ekiro Group

texts.en:
N. Suzan, the chairperson of Akutwala Ekiro Women’s Group, is 29 years old. She is married and cares for her 2 children and 3 other relatives. Although she is married, Suzan's husband is mostly away from home, leaving the responsibility of her home to herself. Suzan is really hard working.

She has been running a restaurant business for 11 years at Mengo hospital and her clients are mostly patients and their caretakers. Over the past 18 months she has received loans of various amounts, as have the other group members.

With her part of this loan, Suzan plans to expand her restaurant by buying more saucepans, plates and forks, which will enable her to prepare more dishes for her customers like matooke (cooked unripened bananas that are wrapped in banana leaves), rice, posho and cassava.

loans.use: Expand the restaurant by buying more utensils.

loans.name: Men

texts.en: Mrs. Men K. S., 51, is the mother of three children who lives in Batambong province, Cambodia. She is employed by a local hospital and makes about $6 a day. Her husband works as a motor-taxi driver and typically earns about $5 per day. Mrs. Men K. S. has applied for a loan of $1,000 to buy a motorcycle so that one of her children can operate a motor-taxi service like her husband does. She believes this will increase the family's income and help improve its standard of living

loans.use: To earn more income by operating a motor-taxi like her husband's.

loans.name: Upper Kawuga C(2063) A Group

texts.en:

M. is 42 years old and is married with 4 children ranging from age 12 to 20 and her children go to school. Each week, M. makes approximately UGX 300000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children and buy a plot of land.

M. is joined in her small group by Martha N., Florence S., Teopist M., and Monica M.. Martha N. has a poultry business and is requesting a loan to expand it. Florence S. also has a poultry business and is requesting a loan to complete the poultry house that is under construction. Teopist M. has a retail shop and is requesting a loan to add stock. Monica M. has a restaurant and is requesting a loan to purchase more furniture and buy food warmers.

loans.use: To invest in restaurant business

loans.name: Ruon

She runs a stand at a local market where she earns about $3 a day selling food and groceries. She hopes to use this loan to expand the inventory of items she has to sell. (In the photograph, we see one of Mrs. Ruon S. N.'s daughters because she was unavailable when the photo was taken.)

loans.use: To purchase more grocery products to sell from a food stall.

loans.name: Upper Kawuga C(2063) B Group

texts.en: The group leader of this small group is Juliet B..  She is currently in the business of livestock farming and is requesting a loan to invest in a piggery business.  Juliet is 25 years old and is married with one child, aged 1.  Each week, Juliet makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan she hopes to be able to invest in a poultry business.  Juliet is joined in her small group by Betty N., Flora N., Mary N., and Rose N..  Betty N. is currently in the business of brick-laying and is requesting a loan to expand her brick business.  Flora N. is currently in the business of second-hand clothes and is requesting a loan to purchase more clothes for sale.  Mary N. is currently in the retail shop business  and is requesting a loan to increase stock.  Rose N. is currently has a grocery store and is requesting a loan to purchase more shop items.

loans.use: To expand livestock business

loans.name: Tes

texts.en: Mr. Tes M. is married with three children and lives Batambong province, Cambodia. He is employed by a private company and makes about $4 a day. His wife works as a seamstress and typically earns around $7 a day. Mr. M. plans to use this loan to buy another sewing machine for his wife so she can expand her business.

loans.use: To expand a tailoring business by buying one more sewing machine.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To expand poultry business

loans.name: Isabel Bernardo

texts.pt:
Isabel Bernardo M. lives with her partner and three children in Maputo, Mozambique. She is in the business of buying coconuts in the province of Inhambane and taking them to South Africa to sell. She joined the credit program as part of the Magoanine group and now, on her second loan cycle, is applying for an individual loan of $275 to improve her coconut business.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva Volunteer.

Isabel Bernardo M., portadora do BI nº 110342133R vive maritalmente mãe de 3 filhos é residente 3 de fevereiro é negociante de cocos compra os cocos em inhambane e vende na Africa do sul entrou no programa como elemento do grupo Magoanine tomava o valor de 1800 agora esta a tomar sozinha esta no 2º ciclo vai tomar o valor de 6000 mt a pagar em 6 meses para aumentar o seu negocio.

loans.use: To invest in coconut business

loans.name: Jero

texts.id:
Using a sewing machine that she owns, R. focuses her efforts on stitching and tailoring clothes. She is capable of producing assorted designs and styles based on the customer order. She has cloth of her own that she keeps ready for this work but she also tailors cloth that customers themselves bring. She is able to get up to Rp. 600,000 each month (USD equivalent $65). Her production costs are not compensated for up front, as customers pay upon receipt after the work is done. R. is self-sufficient and desires a livelihood where she does not have to depend on anyone.

Translated from Bahasa Indonesia by Aarati, Kiva Volunteer.

Bermodalkan mesin jahit yang ia miliki, R. menekuni usaha Menjahit Baju. Berbagai macam model bisa ia penuhi sesuai dengan pesanan. Kain – kain yang ia pakai berasal dari kain yang memang ia sediakan maupun dari pelanggan yang menginginkan dibuat dari kain yang mereka telah bawa. Dia bisa memperoleh keuntungan sampai dengan Rp 600.000,00/bulan. Biaya produksi yang ia keluarkan tidak bisa ia langsung peroleh dari para pelanggan. Hal ini disebabkan mereka bayar di belakang. Walaupun tidak memiliki siapapun untuk ditanggung, R. bertekad untuk tidak menggantungkan hidupnya pada orang lain.

loans.use: To purchase cloth, thread, and other accessories/necessities

loans.name: Christine

texts.fr:
Born around 1975 in Abomey, the historic capital of Benin, Mrs. Christine N. is married and the mother of one child. She sells costume jewelry in the big outdoor market called Dantokpa in Cotonou and manages to get maximum profit from her sales. This makes her the chief breadwinner for her family. Her husband, who produces handicrafts, is not able to support his family completely because his earnings are not consistent.

Christine is now asking for her second loan with us. She counts as one of our best clients because the serious attitude she has shown toward reimbursing her previous loans.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Née vers 1975 dans la capitale historique du Bénin Abomey, Madame Christine N. est mariée et mère d’un enfant. Elle vend des bijoux dans le grand marché DANTOKPA de Cotonou et en tire par sa vente le maximum de profits. Ceci fait d’elle la pourvoyeuse de l’essentiel des besoins de sa famille.Son mari exerçant une activité artisanale n’arrive pas à assumer financièrement ses responsabilités de chef de famille à cause de l’irrégularité de son revenu.

Elle est à son deuxième crédit chez nous. Le sérieux dont elle fait preuve dans le remboursement de ses crédits antérieurs fait d'elle l'une de nos meilleures clientes.

loans.use:
purchasing 20 dozen of various types of costume jewelry: chains, bracelets for men and women, etc.

20 douzaines de Bijoux de diverses catégories à savoir : chaînes, bracelets pour homme et femme

Poor financial support results in poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. When a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from the said client, extends a loan to her, then leases back the same equipment – a process called a ‘sale and leaseback arrangement’.

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of goods in bulk

loans.name: Ruth's Group

texts.en:
‘Two is better than one’ has been a stepping stone for Godfrey Mabike, Rose N., Ruth W. and Margret N.. The group started rearing egg-laying chickens 5 years ago and they have kept the spirit. These chicken are kept at one of the members’ residence and their dream is to see that they rear as many as possible. Currently they have more than 300 layers and they plan to rear broiler chicken as well to prepare mostly for Easter holidays, since broilers take only 2 months to mature.

Each member has a side business from which they draw the funds to cater for the chicken feeds, water and vaccinations. Their customers are mostly restaurants, hotels, shops for the eggs and vendors who roast the chicken.

This loan may seem small but they believe it will help them a lot.

loans.use: Expand their business to include broiler chickens.

loans.name: Sevelina

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 44 year old Sevelina M.. She is married with six children, aged between 8 and 25, and has one other dependent, who is her granddaughter. In 2000, Sevelina established a tailoring business, and now requires a loan in order to purchase material and accessories for her tailoring business. She thanks you for your support.

About SELFINA

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed ‘un-creditworthy’ by financial institutions due to a lack of tangible collateral assets. Poor financial support results in poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. When a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from the said client, extends a loan to her, then leases back the same equipment – a process called a ‘sale and leaseback arrangement’.

loans.use: To purchase material and accessories for her tailoring business.

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbozi, Tanzania! This is 39 year old Lucy N.. She is married with three children, aged 17, 12 and 2. In 2005, Lucy established a bar, and now requires a loan in order to purchase additional stock of beer, liquor, and soft drinks. She thanks you for your support.

It is said that Coca Cola® is one of the most recognized symbols or ‘words’ in the world. And it is true. Even in the most remote villages in Africa, there is usually some kind of ‘bar’ selling Coke, Fanta, and Guiness. The hot weather makes soft drinks all the more appealing; a very cheap marketing tool indeed. This explains why selling soft drinks is such a popular venture, whether you are the CEO of Coca Cola Ltd in the United States or a micro-entrepreneur in Tanzania!

loans.use: To purchase additional stock of beer, liquor, and soft drinks in bulk.

loans.name: Slyvia

texts.en:

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbozi, Tanzania! This is 43 year old Elizabeth N.. She is single with three children, aged 22, 18 and 15. In 2006, Elizabeth established a bar, and now requires a loan in order to purchase additional stocks of beer, liquor, and soft drinks. She thanks you for your support.

It is said that Coca Cola® is one of the most recognized symbols or ‘words’ in the world. And it is true. Even in the most remote villages in Africa, there is usually some kind of ‘bar’ selling Coke, Fanta, and Guiness. The hot weather makes soft drinks all the more appealing; a very cheap marketing tool indeed. This explains why selling soft drinks is such a popular venture, whether you are the CEO of Coca Cola Ltd in the United States or a micro-entrepreneur in Tanzania!
