The floor of their house is dirt and she needs the loan to tile the floor of the living room and the kitchen.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Rosa tiene 46 años, casada, con un hijo de 9 años. Habita en el barrio Hialeah de Managua, considerado uno de los barrios más pobres y con más necesidad de infraestructura de Managua. Ella trabaja como cocinera de un restaurante en un mercado de Managua, lleva seis años dedicándose a este trabajo. Su esposo tiene 42 años y se dedica a la Construcción. Ellos quieren darles mejor condición de vida a su pequeño hijo y a ellos mismos. Han ido mejorando su casa poco a poco, pero todavía les falta mucho por recorrer. El piso de su casa es de tierra y necesita el préstamo para embaldosar el piso de la sala y la cocina.

loans.use: To buy cement and sand to tile the floor of the kitchen and living room of her house.

loans.name: Lazaro Bernardo

texts.es:
Lazarus was born in Jinotepe February 8, 1954. He is married and has 3 male children aged 12, 13 and 15 years. His wife is 48 years old and she is dedicated to taking care of her home and family. At present they reside in the Hialeah neighborhood of Managua. Lazarus act as a security guard and has 4 years experience in this profession. He requests the loan to buy a wooden door for the front door of his house, since the one that is in use has become very deteriorated, and does not provide security for them, since the old thing that it is could break at any moment.

Translated from Spanish by B, Kiva Volunteer.

Lázaro nació en Jinotepe el 8 de Febrero de 1954. Es casado y tiene 3 hijos varones de 12, 13 y 15 años. Su esposa tiene 48 años y se dedica al cuido del hogar y de su familia. Actualmente habitan en el barrio Hialeah de Managua. Lázaro se desemP. como guarda de seguridad, tiene 4 años dedicandose a esta profesión. Solicita el crédito para comprar una puerta de madera para la puerta principal de su casa, ya que la que está en uso se encuentra muy deteriorada, y no les brinda seguridad, ya que por lo vieja que está se rompería en cualquier momento.

loans.use: To replace the wooden door on the front of his house

loans.name: Srey

texts.en: Mrs. Srey C.,39, runs a stand near selling roast beef and duck eggs to the people in her area, making on average around $3 each day in income. Her husband works breeding pigs and driving a motor-taxi making about $3 per day. Two of their children work buying and selling recycling items and the rest are students. Mrs. Srey C. is humbly requests a loan to purchase a motorcycle so one of her children can operate a motor-taxi like her husband. She strongly believes this will help raise her income.

loans.use: To purchase a motorcycle for one of her children so he can operate a motor-taxi

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Duch

texts.en: Mrs. Duch R., 34, works on her rice paddy growing crops and also raises pigs. She typically makes on average around $3 each day in revenue. Her husband works as a policeman earning about $3 each day. Mrs. Duch R. would like to request this loan to purchase another plot of farmland to expand her crops.

loans.use: To purchase another plot of farmland to expand her crops

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Basheeran's Group

texts.en:
Chichawatni is my birth town and I have spent all my life here. It is a small town in Southern Punjab, a large province in Pakistan. I am married with five kids. One of my son operates a leather store and is in need of a loan.

I am borrowing for the second time in my loan group. My group members are: Imtiaz B., who wants a loan for their family’s rickshaw; Munira B. who requires a loan for their chicken butcher's shop; Nosheen B. who is also borrowing for her business; and Nasira B. who sells flowers.

loans.use: Expand our current business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Arubaine 1 Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Halima S.. She is currently in the business of used clothing and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Halima is 21 years old and is married with one son aged 2. Halima makes approximately UGX 10000 in profits and with the increased profits from her loan, she hopes to join up her profits with her husband's income so they can buy a piece of land. Halima has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Halima is joined in her small group by Mary Nadugwa, Zula N., Zam G., and Nalongo O.. Mary Nadugwa has a business in charcoal sales and wants to increase stock. Zula N. is currently operating a business in selling charcoal and wants a loan to add in business. Zam G. operates a retail shop and wants to increase stock. Nalongo O. is currently in the business of selling new clothes and is requesting a loan to add in the retail business.

loans.use: To expand clothes business

loans.name: Arubaine 2 Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Mary A.. She currently sells charcoal and is requesting a loan to purchase more sacks of charcoal. Mary is 38 years old and is married to a clearing agent. She has 5 children ranging from age 7 to 18 and her children go to school. Each week, Mary makes approximately UGX 10000 in profits and with the increased profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children. Mary has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Mary is joined in her small group by Sarah N., Shamira O., Hadija M., and Nuru R.. Sarah N. owns a small hotel and wants to buy more furniture. Shamira O. sells new clothes and wants a loan to increase stock. Hadija M. and Nuru R. also sell clothes and want to increase stock.

loans.use: To expand charcoal business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Suriya's Group

texts.en: "I am Suriya B. from Chichawatni, a small town in Pakistan. I am married with five kids. Last year, I took a loan for one of my sons who is a butcher and sells meat. Now, another of my sons wants a loan to start a small newspaper agency. I am also requesting loans for my group members. These women are hardworking entrepreneurs and needy as well. Let me now introduce them to you: Muniran A.'s family runs a tannery; Khadija B. wants to buy a new photostat machine; Yasmeen B. will invest her share of our loan in her family’s ready-made garment business. In addition, my last member, Zainab B., requires a loan for her family’s furniture business."

loans.use: Start a newspaper agency

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Parwen's Group

texts.en:
"I am a group leader and my name is Parween K.. I am married and live with my husband in a small town, Chichawatni, Pakistan. My brother is a rickshaw driver and he needs to replace his older rickshaw. I help him because he gives me a reasonable rate of profit out of his business.

Last year, I bought a sewing machine to start my stitching business with my share of his profits.

My group members are: Rukhsana B. who requires a loan for her flower business; Manzoora B. who will invest her share of our loan in her family’s envelope business; Shaheen Zulfiqar who wants a loan to improve their restaurant; and Rubina B. who will use the loan to expand their ready-made garment business.

loans.use: Replace older rickshaw with a new one

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Arubaine 3 Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Barbara N.. She owns a beauty salon and is requesting a loan to expand her salon business. Barbara is 23 years old and is married. Her husband is an engineer. She has 3 children ranging from age 8 months to 5 and two of her children go to school. Each week, Barbara makes approximately UGX 10000 in profits and with the increased profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children . Barbara has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before to buy hair oils and salon mirrors and the loan was paid back on time.

Barbara is joined in her small group by Alice W., Scovia N., Racheal N., and Eddy N.. Alice W. has a business in charcoal sales and wants to increase stock. Scovia N. is currently operating a business in selling yellow bananas and wants a loan to add in stock. Racheal N. operates a business of selling charcoal and wants to construct a shade for the charcoal. Eddy N. is currently in the business of selling new shoes and is requesting a loan to purchase more shoes to sell.

loans.use: To expand salon business

loans.name: Yasmeen's Group

texts.en:
"My name is Yasmen A.. I am the mother of eight and all of them are under 16. All of my kids attend school. We run a business selling shoes. My husband generates decent profits out of this business.

Please give loans to my group members as well: Nasim Y. requires a loan for their shop; Aqila B. requires a loan for her family’s mobile phone store; Rukhsana B. wants to improve their fruit business; and Sarweri G. wants to start a tea stall. All of us are neighbors and wish each other a prosperous life."

loans.use: Expand our shoe business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Arubaine 4 Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Elixabeth A.. She is currently in the business of selling charcoal and is requesting a loan to increase inventory in her charcoal business. Elixabeth is 44 years old and is married to a business man. She has 7 children ranging from age 13 to 27 and three of them go to school. Each week, Elixabeth makes approximately UGX 50000 in profits and with the increased profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children. Elixabeth has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before which she paid back on time.

Elixabeth is joined in her small group by Alice A., Erios N., Vivian Nakaibale, and Rose N.. Alice A. has a business selling charcoal and wants to start selling firewood. Erios N. is currently operating a business selling charcoal and wants a loan to increase stock. Vivian Nakaibale sells used clothes and wants to purchase more clothes to sell. Rose N. currently sells new clothes and is requesting a loan to expand business.

loans.use: To increase inventory in charcoal business

loans.name: Arubaine 5 Group

texts.en:
The leader of this group is Maliza N.. She sells charcoal and is requesting a loan to purchase more charcoal from villages. Maliza is 40 years old and is married with a husband who sells dry foods. She has 4 children ranging from age 6 to 25. Each week, Maliza makes approximately UGX 50000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan she hopes to be able to construct a residential house. Maliza has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 500000 in order to invest it in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Maliza is joined in her group by Racheal N., Rose N. and Rebecca M.. Racheal N. sells charcoal and wants to expand her business. Rose N. sells new shoes and wants a loan to increase her stock. Rebecca M. sells used clothes and wants to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand charcoal business.

loans.name: Arubaine Ca Group

texts.en:
The leader of this group is Sophia N.. She sells matooke and is requesting a loan to invest in her food business. Sophia is 30 years old and is married. Her husband sells dry foods. She has 5 children ranging from age 2 to 12 and her children go to school. Each week, Sophia makes approximately UGX 25000 in profits and she hopes to use her loan to cater for the needs of the children and the home at largel. Sophia has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 and the loan was paid back on time.

Also in Sophia's group are Sarah W., Hadija G., Saida A. and Fatuma K.. Sarah W. sells used clothes and wants to expand her business. Hadija G. sells yellow bananas and wants a loan to expand her business. Saida A. sells used clothes and wants to start up a shoe business. Fatuma K. currently runs a small hotel and is requesting a loan to buy more hotel equipment.

loans.use: To expand matooke food business

loans.name: Arubaine Cd Group

texts.en:
The leader of this group is Robina M.. She sells dry fish and is requesting a loan to invest in her business. Robina is 49 years old and is married. Her husband is a business man. She has 8 children ranging from age 5 to 22 and her children go to school. Each week, Sophia makes approximately UGX 40000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan she hopes to be able pay school fees for the children. Sophia has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 250000 and the loan was paid back on time.

Sophia is joined in her group by Gorette Nabududuwa, Mary N. and Mary A.. All three are in the business of selling charcoal. Gorette Nabududuwa and Mary N. both wish to expand their businesses. Mary A. wants a loan to construct a shade for her charcoal.

loans.use: To expand dry fish business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Arubaine Cb Group

texts.en:
The leader of this group is Rispa L.. She has a drug shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more drugs for sale. Rispa is 27 years old and is married. Her husband owns a retail shop. She has one child aged 6 who goes to school. Each week, Rispa makes approximately UGX 50000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan she hopes to add more stock to her business. Rispa has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 250000 and the loan was paid back on time.

Rispa is joined in her group by Frida O., Hadija M. and Hadija M.. Frida O. has a business selling new clothes and wants to expand her business. Hadija M. has a retail shop and wants a loan to increase stock. Hadija Muhamed operates a charcoal business she wants to expand.

loans.use: To expand drug shop business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Arubaine Cc Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Kasifa N.. She is in the business of charcoal sales and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Kasifa is 22 years old and is married with a husband who owns a retail shop. She has 2 children aged 1 and 2. Each week, Kasifa makes approximately UGX 80000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan she hopes to be able to buy a plot of land. Kasifa has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 150000 in order to invest it in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Kasifa is joined in her group by Fatuma M., Yuwusi A. and Bayan M.. Fatuma M. has a business selling used clothes and wants to increase her stock. Yuwusi A. operates a business in selling used clothing and wants a loan to expand business. Bayan M. operates a business of clothing sales and wants to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand charcoal business.

loans.name: Arubaine Ce Group

texts.en:
The leader of this group is Sida N.. She sells charcoal and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Sida is 36 years old and married. She has 10 children ranging from age 2 to 22 and her children go to school. Each week, Sida makes approximately UGX 150000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children. Sida has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 in order to construct a store for her charcoal business and the loan was paid back on time.

Sida is joined in her group by Ruth N., Rose N., Lalia N., and K. Namazzi. Ruth N. is also in the charcoal business and wants to expand her stock. Rose N. sells new clothes and wants a loan to increase stock. Lalia N. sells charcoal and wants to invest in her business. K. Namazzi also sells charcoal and is requesting a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand charcoal business.

loans.name: Solo Fa Group

texts.en:
The leader of this small group is Betty Eitoto. She owns a salon and is requesting a loan to buy more salon equipment. Betty is 22 years old and is single. She has one child aged 7 who goes to school. Each week, Betty makes approximately UGX 50000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan she hopes to be able to pay house rent and pay school fees for her daughter. Betty has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Betty is joined in her group by Sharon A. and Lumala A.. Sharon A. sells fresh fruits and wants to expand her business. Lumala A. sells new shoes and wants a loan to add to her stock.

loans.use: To expand salon business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Sek

texts.en:
A 72-year-old widow with two children, Mrs. Sek O., works on her farmland growing rice and a variety of vegetables, earning on average around $0.50 each day. One of her children owns musical instruments and hires them out to the people in his area, specifically whenever a particular wedding is celebrated. It enables him to earn generally about $3 each day in profit. Her other child works with her in the rice field.

Mrs. Sek O. has humbly requested a loan to purchase more musical instruments for her son so that he can meet his rental customers’ needs.

loans.use: To purchase more musical instruments for her son so he can meet his rental customers’ needs

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Sor

texts.en:
Mrs. Sor I., 32, is the mother of four children and lives wI. her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She works buying recyclable items from the people in her community and reselling them to her local recycling plant. She also works works growing rice on her piece of land. She can generally earn about $3/day in income. Meanwhile, her husband drives a horse-cart carrying salt to sell everywhere around his community and typically makes about $3 per day in revenue.

One of their children works as a carpenter making wooden doors, windows, chairs and various kinds of wooden furniture. The other children are enrolled in school.

Mrs. Sor I. has lately requested this loan to purchase more seeds to expand her little farm and purchase more wood to supply her son’s carpentry business.

loans.use: To purchase more seeds to expand her farm and wood to supply her son’s carpentry business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Hom

texts.en:
Mrs. Hom P., 49, is a widow with four children and works on her rice paddy growing rice and vegetables, making collectively around $4 each day in income. Her married daughter is employed by a garment factory; another child attends school and the other children work producing incense to sell to the people in their area.

Mrs. Hom P. hopes to use this loan to purchase another rice paddy to expand her crops to enable her to generate an additional profit. (She is pictured with her two little grand-daughters.)

loans.use: To purchase another rice paddy to expand her crops so she can generate additional profit

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Solo Fc Group

texts.en:
The leader of this group is Jesca A.. She is currently in the business of selling used clothes and is requesting a loan to invest in her business. Jesca is 48 years old and is a widow. She has 7 children ranging from age 10 to 30 and five of them go to school. Each week, Jesca makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children. Jesca has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 150000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Jesca is joined in her group by Irene T., Aisha N., Doreen A., and Agnes A.. Irene T. has a business selling used clothes and wants to increase her stock. Aisha N. operates a business selling spare parts and wants a loan to expand her business. Doreen A. operates a business of selling used clothes and wants to add stock. Agnes A. is in the business of fruits and vegetable selling and is requesting a loan to purchase more fruits and vegetables.

loans.use: To expand clothing business.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Tororo Road A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this group is Salimati M.. She sells used clothes and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Sulimati is 25 years old and is married. Her husband has a commercial motorcycle (boda boda) for work. She has 4 children ranging from age 2 to 9 and three of them go to school. Each week, Sulimati makes approximately UGX 30000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children. Sulimati has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 200000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Sulimati is joined in her small group by Alaisha G. and Christine N. Alaisha G. has a business used clothes and wants to increase her stock. Christine N. is currently operating a business in used clothing sales and wants a loan to purchase more clothes for sale.

loans.use: To expand clothes business.

loans.name: Mey

texts.en:
Mrs. Mey S., 38, works with her husband on their farm growing rice and raising horses, making about $3 each day in income. This couple has seven children. One of their children works making incense; another one is a garment worker; one is enrolled in school and the rest are married and live separately.

Mrs. Mey S. is humbly requesting a loan to expand her livestock by adding another healthy horse to breed so as to generate more profit.

loans.use: To purchase another horse to breed

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for CREDIT, a partner of World Relief - Oct 26, 2008)

loans.name: Mey

texts.en: Mrs. Mey S., 38, works with her husband on their farm growing rice crops and raising horse making totally about $3 each day of income. This couple has seven children. One of their children works making incenses; another one works as a garment worker; one of whom is enrolled in school and the rest of which are married and stay separately. Mrs. Mey S. is humble to request for a loan to expand her livestock by adding more healthy horse to breed for generating more profit in the next twelve to eight months.

loans.use: To purchase more horses to breed.

loans.name: Marach B(I) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this group is R. Ismail. She is currently in the business of new shoes and is requesting a loan to increase her stock. R. is 23 years old and is married with a husband who sells shoes. She has 2 children aged two-and-a-half and four and they both go to school.

Each week, R. makes approximately UGX 50000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan she hopes to be able to construct a house. R. has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 400000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

R. is joined in her small group by Fatuma S., Farida S. and Zaina N.. Fatuma S. has a business in shoe sales that she wants to expand. Farida S. is currently operating a business selling new clothes and wants a loan to purchase more clothes for S.. Zaina N. operates a business of dry fish and wants to expand her fish business.

loans.use: To expand shoe business.

loans.name: Tuinuane E Group

texts.en:
Salma Y., age 54, is a widow with 4 children (ages 40, 38, 35, and 33). She has a business selling food, which she began 26 years ago. She opens her business from 7am to 4pm daily, and she makes a monthly profit of about $158.

In the past, Salma took out 2 previous loans with Tujijenge Tanzania to expand her food business. She now hopes for a new loan to further expand the same business. She will share this loan with her sub group members who have businesses dealing in selling food, a kiosk, selling cosmetics, clothes and a saloon.

In the picture, Salma is 1st on the right.

loans.use: to expand our individual businesses

payments.comment: Incorrect loan term. Loan is now finished.

loans.name: Marachi B(Ii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Saida Z.. She is currently in the business of charcoal sales and is requesting a loan to expand her business. Saida is 39 years old and is married to a farmer. She has 6 children ranging from age 12 to 20 and only three go to school.

Each week, Saida makes approximately UGX 200000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan she hopes to be able to pay school fees for the children. Saida has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 600000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Saida is joined in her small group by Jane Nansirumbi, Sarah A. and Rose N.. Jane Nansirumbi has a butcher shop and wants to add to her business. Sarah A. is currently operating a business selling new clothes and wants a loan to expand her clothing business. Rose N. operates a business of new clothes and wants to increase the stock of clothes for sale.

loans.use: To expand charcoal business

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for BRAC Uganda - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Hajara

texts.en: Hajara A. is a single 24-year-old woman who has been a cosmetics trader for the past 4 years. She is requesting a loan of $275 to buy more creams and cosmetics for sale. Business has been very strong recently. The products pictured in her basket are literally the last of her available supplies. She hopes that this loan will increase her income and ensure that her product line does not become depleted as it is currently.

loans.use: To purchase additional creams and cosmetics for sale.

loans.name: Marach B(Iii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Shalima Nakamya. She owns a drug shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more drugs for sale.

Shalima is 23 years old and is married with a husband who is a business man. Each week, Shalima makes approximately UGX 300000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to construct a house. Shalima has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 600000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Shalima is joined in her small group by Beatrice N., Isha W. and Ali Z.. Beatrice N. sells new clothes and wants to add to her business. Isha W. is currently operating a business in charcoal sales and wants a loan to expand and become a wholesaler. Ali Z. operates a business of used clothing and wants to increase her stock of clothes.

loans.use: To buy more drugs for sale in her drug shop.

loans.name: Marach B(Iii) Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Shalima Nakamya. She owns a drug shop and is requesting a loan to purchase more drus for sale. Shalima is 23 years old and is married with a husband who is a business man. Each week, Shalima makes approximately UGX 300000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to construct a house. Shalima has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 600000 in order to invest in her business and the loan was paid back on time.

Shalima is joined in her small group by Beatrice N., Isha W. and Ali Z.. Beatrice N. sells new clothes and wants to add in clothe business. Isha W. is currently operating a business in charcoal sales and wants a loan to expand and become a wholesaler. Ali Z. operates a business of used clothing and wants to increase stock of clothes.

loans.use: To buy more drugs for sale thus expand business

loans.name: Harriet

texts.en: Harriet O. is a seamstress who has been in business for the past 16 years. She is a married mother of 3 young children and she supports her family by selling the clothes she makes in her shop. She is requesting a loan of $525 to buy additional fabrics needed to further expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional fabrics to further expand her business.

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en: Vivian T. owns a road-side hairdressing salon in Cape Coast, where she has worked for 6 years. She is a single, 25-year-old woman who works very hard and is seeking $525 to buy hairdressing products to meet the demands of her loyal client base. In addition, she hopes that the additional capital will allow her to expand her client base by offering new products to attract new customers.

loans.use: To buy hairdressing products to meet the demands of her loyal client base and to attract new customers.

loans.name: Afari

texts.en: Afari G. is a single mother who buys and sells cassava, corn, and plantains to local villagers. People buy these products to make “fufu,” a very popular dish in Ghana, which is made by cooking cassava and plantains and then pounding them together in a bowl so that they become a condensed paste. She supports her 5 children and is requesting $525 to buy more cassava and plantains for her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional cassava and plantains for her business.

loans.name: Olivia

texts.en: Olivia O. is a 25-year-old, married mother of 2 young children. Olivia is a baker and she sells her baked goods at the market. She is requesting $325 to buy flour and margarine for baking purposes. In addition, her oven recently broke and is currently being fixed, so she would also use these funds to help with the repair costs.  She hopes that this loan will allow her to generate additional income to help support her family.

loans.use: To buy flour and margarine for baking and to repair her oven.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary A. is a fishmonger who buys fresh fish directly from fishermen, brings the fish home for preservation (smoking), and later sells the smoked fish to her customers. She is married with a child. Her business is doing very well. She wishes to increase her sales to meet the increasing demand for her fish. Mary is hereby seeking $225 of additional capital to buy more fresh fish for processing and to then sell the fish to her customers.

loans.use: To purchase additional fresh fish for processing to increase sales.

loans.name: Edith

texts.en: Edith F. is a 24-year-old trader. She does not yet own her own trading stand, so she carries her goods around to various markets selling shoes and garments. She is married and has 1 young child.  She is requesting $525 to further expand her selection of shoes and garments so she can increase her income and reach more prospective clients.

loans.use: To further expand her selection of shoes and garments.

loans.name: Isha

texts.en:
Isha N. is a trader who is involved in the production of food. Specifically, she uses corn to prepare a local meal known as "kenkey," which is extremely popular in her country. She is married and has 4 children. She works very hard to support her husband and to pay for her family’s expenses. Her business is doing very well, so she wants to increase her production to meet the demand of her customers.

Isha is seeking $500 of additional capital to enable her buy more corn to improve upon her "kenkey" production business.

loans.use: To purchase additional corn to improve her "kenkey" production business.

loans.name: Lucia's Group

texts.en:
Isabel, Paulina, and Lucia have been members of the community bank “Luz Divina” for six, ten, and fifteen years respectively. In the community bank they have learned to save, be responsible, punctual, and try to improve themselves day by day.

Isabel is 40 years old. She lives with her partner and son. Isabel has had a store selling food staples such as flour, sugar, and rice for six years. One year ago she started selling pre paid phone cards.

On the other hand, Paulina is 40 years old. She is a single mother and has three children. Paulina has a store where she sells food staples, fruits and vegetables. Paulina started her business with a lone from the community bank, and little by little has expanded her merchendise. In addition Paulina sells prepared food form her store. Paulina is thinking of opening a restaurant.

Lucia is 51 years old. She is a widow and has five children. Lucia, together with her daughter, makes breads that they cell at the regional transportation center. Additionally, in her free time Lucia washes clothing and sells fruit. Isabel, Paulina, and Lucia need loans of 300, 900, and 450 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use to buy pre paid phone cards, sugar, rice, soap, detergent, soft drinks, flour, and fire wood.

One of the most important aspects of the community bank is the interest earning savings account each associate has. Isabel, Paulina, and Lucia plan to use their savings to expand their businesses, and open a restaurant. Their dreams are to open a market, that their son studies at the university, to own house, and to help their daughter start her own business.

loans.use: Isabel, Paulina, and Lucia need loans of 300, 900, and 450 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use to buy pre paid phone cards, sugar, rice, soap, detergent, soft drinks, flour, and fire wood.

loans.name: Alminda Albina's Group

texts.en:
Vilma and Alminda have been members of the community bank “Luz Divina” for four months and seven years respectively.  In the community bank they have learned to be punctual, responsible, independent, and how to handle money and makes decisions.
Vilma is 27 years old, and by profession a nurse.  She sells grains in the markets of Ayacucho.  Now, with the help of her father, she is growing potatoes and corn.  In addition Vilma works as a nurse.
Meanwhile Alminda is 46 years old.  She is married and has four children.  Alminda has a business preserving fish.  She sells her products throughout the region of Ayacucho.  She is planning to open a new business selling cebiche, a traditional dish made from marinating fish.  Eventually she would like to have several cebiche restaurants.  
Vilma and Alminda need loans of 300 and 1500 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use to buy fertilizers, pay laborers, tables, and chairs.
One of the key aspects of the community bank is the interest earning savings account each associate has.  Vilma and Alminda plan to use their savings to expand their business, pay for their children’s education, and get a nursing specialization.  Their dreams are that their children will be professionals, they can help their family and younger siblings, and to be secure economically

loans.use: Vilma and Alminda need loans of 300 and 1500 soles (3 soles = $1), which they will use to buy fertilizers, pay laborers, tables, and chairs.

loans.name: Gifty

texts.en:
Gifty G. is a trader who sells ceramics, such as plates, as well as raw materials. She is a single parent of 4 children. She works very hard to meet the needs of her family. She wants to generate additional income by increasing her sales.

Gifty is seeking $525 of additional capital to buy more ceramics (plates) to increase her sales.

loans.use: To purchase additional ceramics (plates) to increase sales.

loans.name: Ljeposava

texts.en:
Ljeposava is 40 years old woman and she is not married. She lives in the small town of Derventa with her 10 year old child who goes to primary school. She owns a flower- shop, but she does not have her own place 
(She rents a place for the flower shop).  She intends to use her loan in the amount of $775 for purchasing goods for the shop.  Her wish is to improve offerings in her flower shop. Ljeposava hopes that she will increase her income and secure a good future for her son.

loans.use: Purchasing goods for the shop.

loans.name: Fati

texts.en:
Fati R. is a distributor. She buys beans, maize, ground nuts, and other such foods in bulk and distributes them in smaller quantities to her customers. She is married and has 3 children. She is working very hard to support her husband and to meet her family’s financial needs. Demand for her goods has increased, so she wants to increase her sales.

Fati is seeking $525 of additional capital to enable her buy more beans, maize, and ground nuts to meet the needs of her customers.

loans.use: To purchase additional beans, maize, and ground nuts in bulk to meet the needs of her customers.

loans.name: Icah

texts.en: Icah, 28, is married to S. and has three daughters. The couple runs a grocery store from home, earning $20 a day. Icah is a member of MBK and would like a loan of $125 to buy new inventory for her store. With the extra income, she hopes to pay  for her children's education. She agrees to repay this loan within 12 months.

loans.use: Restock her grocery store and diversify inventory

loans.name: Yan

texts.en: Yan T., 46, is married to Anton and has four children. She runs a beauty salon from her home and could earn $25 a week. But the income is not regular, fluctuating according to how many clients she has. She is a member of MBK and would like a loan of $125 to buy salon equipment, add to her business capital, and make her client base more stable. She agrees to repay this loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To buy salon equipment

loans.name: Sutianah

texts.en: Sutianah, 39, has five children. She runs a small shop from home where she sells snacks, flavored ices, etc., earning $15 a day. Her husband, S., works as security guard and earns $60 a month. She is asking for a loan of $125 to expand her business. She is a member of MBK and agrees to repay this loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To increase inventory in her food shop

loans.name: Yeyen

texts.en: Yeyen, 34, has three children. She runs a grocery store from her home, earning $18 a day. Her husband, T., operates a printing workshop at home, but his income is variable, depending on the size of orders. Yeyen is a member of MBK and would like a loan of $125 to restock her store and add new inventory. She hopes to earn enough to pay tuition for her children. She agrees to repay this loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To increase inventory in her grocery store

loans.name: Yuli

texts.en: Yuli, 30, has three children aged 12, 8, and  2. She sells sheets, blankets, 'sarongs, and men's and women's apparel door-to-door in neighboring villages. She earns $30 a week. Her husband, S., earns very little in his job as a bus driver. She is a member of MBK and would like a loan of $125 to add to her business capital. She will repay this loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To buy clothing for resale

loans.name: Siti

texts.en: Siti N., 29, and her husband have one child. She sells clothes on credit door-to-door around the villages and earns $25 a week. Her husband, Tulus, works at a construction site and earns $30 a month. She is a member of MBK and would like a loan of $100 to expand her business. She has agreed to repay this loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To buy clothing for resale

loans.name: Eti

texts.en: Eti, 33, is married to D., who has no fixed job. They have three children. To support her family, she sells sheets, bedspreads, and clothing on credit, earning $100 a month. She is a member of MBK. She would like a loan of $75 to increase her inventory. She will repay this loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To increase inventory of linens and clothing

loans.name: Nurjanah

texts.en: Nurjanah, 32, has four children and is married to A., who is unemployed. To support the family, she sells coconut rice, cooked meals, noodles, fried snacks, and other dishes from her food stall. She earns $20 a day. She is asking for a loan of $100 to expand her business. As a member of MBK, she has agreed to repay this loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To buy supplies for her food stand

loans.name: Sadiah

texts.en: Sadiah, 58, is married to A. and has one child. To help support her family, she sells coconut rice, fried snacks, cakes, and other foods door to door around the villages. She earns $15 a day. She has joined MBK and would like a loan of $100 to increase her business capital. She agrees to repay this loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To buy ingredients for snack foods sold door to door

loans.name: Rosa Ines

texts.es:
The production and sale of tortillas is the business in which Mrs Rosa Ines Juarez has dedicated herself for 25 years in her humble house in the municipality of El Sauce de Leon in Nicaragua. She started her business with small savings that she obtained from her previous business which was washing and ironing clothes by request. It is necessary to emphasize that Mrs. Rosa is a single mother and she faces the necessity of taking care of her little son and a small granddaughter of school age. Her difficult seconomic situation puts her in a place where she works with a lot of strength and desire to better her life. Also it is necessary to emphasize that the business of Mrs. Rosa needs to improve its infrastructure because it does not have a roof she only uses leaves to cover her place and furthermore she needs to acquire firewood and the dough to produce the tortillas. For this reason she went to Ceprodel so that she could benefit from credits that allow her to better her business and in this manner take her son and granddaughter out of the neighborhood they inhabit.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

La elaboración y venta de tortillas es el negocio a que se dedica la señora Rosa Inés J. desde hace 25 años en su humilde casa de habitación en el municipio de El Sauce de León en Nicaragua. Su negocio lo inicia con pocos ahorros que los obtuvo por medio de su anterior negocio que era lavado y planchado de ropa a quien se lo solicitara.

Es necesario destacar que la señora Rosa es madre soltera y con la gran necesidad de mantener a un pequeño hijo y una pequeña nieta en edad escolar. Su difícil situación económica da lugar a que trabaje con mucho esfuerzo para mejorar su condición de vida. También es necesario destacar que el negocio de la señora Rosa necesita mejorar la infraestructura por lo que no posee techo sino que utiliza hojas de palera para cubrir su local y además d esto necesita adquirir la leña y la masa para elaborar las tortillas.

Por esta razón es que acude a Ceprodel para ser beneficiada con créditos que le permitan mejorar su negocio y de esta manera sacar adelante a sus hijo y pequeña nieta.

loans.use: To purchase corn and wood.

loans.name: Candida Rosa

texts.es:
Candida Rosa is a very stressed woman originally of the municipality of El Sauce in the city of Leon in Nicaragua. For awhile she has forced herself to better the condition of her business because she is the mother of 2 children who have the necessity to study because they are young. She began her business in her house 12 years ago and now she has a big problem to fix because she does not have the money to buy the products she sells. Because of this she went to Ceprodel for assistance and for the last 2 years she has benefited from them with credits that have enabled her to supply her business and in this way give her children the education they need.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

Candida Rosa es una dama muy esforzada originaria del municipio de El Sauce en la ciudad de León en Nicaragua. Por mucho tiempo ha venido esforzándose por mejorar la condición de su negocio debido a que es madre de 2 hijos con la necesidad de estudiar por ser menores de edad.

Su negocio lo inicia en su casa de habitación desde hace 12 años y hoy en día atraviesa una gran necesidad como lo es que no posee el dinero suficiente para la adquisición de sus productos. Es por este motivo que asiste a Ceprodel quien desde hace 2 años la ha beneficiado con créditos que según cuenta le han be4neficiado para surtir su negocio y de esta manera brindarle la educación a sus pequeños que tanto lo necesitan.

loans.use: To purchase products for her store.

loans.name: Manuel De Jesús

texts.es:
For the past three years, Mr. Manuel M. has dedicated himself to running an electrical automotive repair shop in the Sauce district of León, Nicaragua. He gained his skills in the repair of cars and motorcycles three years ago, which is when he began his business.

Manuel is the father of a young school-aged son, and for this reason he exerts himself every day in order to provide his child with an education and to supply all of his child's needs.

In spite of his difficult economic situation, Mr. Manuel M. has managed to maintain his immediate family and to better his financial circumstances. He has done this thanks to the support of the lending organization Ceprodel, which over the past year has given him a total of 10 credits that he has used to improve the condition of his business.

Currently Manuel needs to invest in the purchase of tools since the ones he owns are in disrepair. In addition, he needs to purchase new tools in order to continue providing his clients with high quality service.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

Desde hace 3 años, en el municipio de el Sauce en la ciudad de León, el señor Manuel M. se dedica al negocio de taller de electricidad automotriz teniendo destrezas en la reparación de automóviles y motocicletas desde hace 3 años que es el tiempo en que inicio su negocio.

Es padre de un pequeño hijo en edad escolar y por esta razón día a día se esfuerza para brindarle su educación y suplir todas sus necesidades.

A pesar de la difícil situación económica que atraviesa el señor Manuel Matus, ha logrado mantener su núcleo familiar y mejorar su condición económica. Esto lo ha realizado gracias al apoyo que le ha brindado Ceprodel desde hace un año con un total de 10 créditos que los ha utilizado para mejorar la condición de su negocio.

Su necesidad actualmente es la urgencia de invertir en la compra de herramientas debido a que las que posee se encuentran en mal estado y además debe de adquirir otras nuevas herramientas que nunca ha tenido para continuar brindando a sus clientes un servicio de alta calidad.

loans.use: To purchase tools for the repair of cars and motorcycles

loans.name: Comité Kyry Aty Group

texts.es:
The committee is comprised of 15 female employees of the Cabañas de Caacupé company. The majority of the members work cultivating and selling garden plants. They have been living in the neighborhood for a long time and help each other sell their products.

The group is currently in its 5th cycle of the “Mujeres Emprendedoras” (Women Entrepreneurs) committee, in which each member receives an average loan of 920.00 Guaraní.

The committee started thanks to one of our representatives who campaigned in these women’s neighborhood. Beatriz, the group leader, says that the group of women has decided that this summer, they will display their products in the city of San Bernardino, which is the country’s top summer attraction.

They will invest this loan in the purchase of fertilizer, garden plants, and flowerpots. The women who own general stores will invest the loan in the purchase of sugar, meat, herbs, flour, milk, charcoal, and assorted beverages.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

El comité está compuesto por 15 señoras trabajadoras de la compañía Cabañas de Caacupé, la mayoría de las integrantes se dedican al cultivo y ventas de plantas para jardín, son personas antiguas del barrios y todas se ayudan para poder comercializar sus productos.

Actualmente el grupo se encuentra en el 5 ciclo del programa de comité de Mujeres Emprendoras, y la misma están siendo beneficiada con un crédito promedio de gs. 920.000 cada integrantes.

El comité se inició gracias a la promoción que realizo uno de nuestros oficiales de crédito en el barrio de estas señoras. Beatriz, la titular del grupo, comenta que el grupo de mujeres en este verano, han decidido ir a exponer sus productos en la ciudad de San Bernardino, ya que esta ciudad es la atracción veraniega del país.

El crédito que solicitan lo invertirán en la compra de abono, plantas para jardín, macetas, y las señoras que poseen despensas lo invertirán en la compra de azúcar, carne, yerba, harina, leche, carbón, y bebidas de todo tipo.

loans.use: Purchase of fertilizer, garden plants, flowerpots, sugar, meat, herbs, flour, milk, charcoal, and assorted beverages

loans.name: Sofia

texts.es:
I need to build an additional room in my patio because my husband and I need more space. Our home is very small since it is public housing, so we would like to expand our house. However, we will have to expand it little by little due to our difficult financial situation. I am requesting $500.00 USD in order to construct an extra room in my house.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

“Tengo la necesidad de hacer un cuarto en el patio de mi vivienda ya que mi esposo y yo necesitamos más espacio porque la casa es de interés social y son muy reducidas, tenemos la intención de ir haciendo nuestra casa más grande pero tendrá que ser poco a poco debido a que la situación económica esta muy difícil” Solicito $ 500.00 dlls para construir un cuarto en mi vivienda.

loans.use: Construction of a room

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Fundación para la Vivienda Progresiva (FVP), a partner of CHF International - Oct 22, 2008)

loans.name: San Francisco Group

texts.es:
The committee “San Francisco Group” is made up of 15 working women from the neighborhood of San Francisco in the city of Caacupé, Paraguay. They all make and sell “chipas” (traditional corn and cheese breads) as walking saleswomen. They are in their sixth cycle of the program sponsored by Mujeres Emprededoras (Enterprising Women), and their group is unusual in that it is the only committee made up of women who are all dedicated to the same activity. Generally group members pursue different endeavors.

The women of this group are dedicated to the making and sale of “chipas.” La chipa is a typicial dish in Paraguay, made from a base of starch, eggs and milk. It is similar to a cheese bread and eaten a lot in the region, so the demand for these products is quite high. La chipa is baked in a “tatakua,” which is a mud oven. The women of San Francisco Group prepare the chipa in the early morning so that at first light they can sell their baked breads fresh from the oven.

Mrs. Cándida L. notes that this group of women has a strong sense of solidarity. She recalls that two of the group members had health problems recently and the committee took action in order to help the ill women manage the costs of hospitalization and the purchase of medicines.

The group is requesting credit in order to purchase ingredients such as eggs, starch, cheese, milk, and other items for the making of their products.

Translated from Spanish by Debra Faszer-McMahon, Kiva Volunteer.

El comité está integrado por 15 señoras trabajadoras del barrio San Francisco de la ciudad de Caacupé, todas se dedican a la elaboración y venta de chipas en forma ambulante, ellas están en el 6to. Ciclo del programa comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras y tiene una característica peculiar, es el único comité integrado por señoras que se dedican a una misma actividad, ya que por lo general las integrantes poseen actividades diferentes.

Estas señoras se dedican a la elaboración y venta de “chipas”. La chipa, es una comida típica de nuestro país, elaborado a base de almidón, huevos y leche, es parecido a un pan con queso y bastante consumido en nuestro país por lo que la venta de estos productos es bastante alta. La chipa es hormeada en “tatakua” que es un horno hecho de barro. Estas mujeres preparan durante la madrugada sus chipas para que a primeras horas de la mañana puedan vender sus chipas recién salidas del horno.

La señora Candida manifiesta que éste grupo de mujeres tiene un alto sentido de solidaridad cuenta que dos de las integrantes tuvieron problemas de salud recientemente y el comité realizó actividades para poder ayudar a costear los gastos de la internación y compra de medicamentos.

El crédito lo solicitan para la compra de ingredientes como huevos, almidón, queso, leche entre otros para elaborar sus productos.

loans.use: For the purchase of ingredients used to make chipas, such as starch, cheese, vegetable oil, firewood, flour, milk, and other products.

loans.name: Comite Renacer Group

texts.es:
The committee is comprised of 17 female workers from the Conavi neighborhood in the city of Caacupé. The group is currently in its 4th cycle of the “Mujeres Emprendedoras” (Women Entrepreneurs) committee. Each member is receiving an average loan of 635.00 Guaraní.

The committee was started thanks to the leadership of Mrs. María S., who found out that Fundación Paraguaya offers a program designed exclusively for working women. She invited her colleagues and neighbors to join the program, and that is how the group called “Renacer” emerged.

The women all own different types of businesses, like general stores, beverage sales, preparation and sales of chipas (Paraguayan bread), kiosks, and plant sales.

The committee is currently planning to carry out beautification projects such as cleaning up sidewalks and empty lots, and improving the plaza and the neighborhood soccer field so that the children can have a safe recreational place.

Mrs. Carolina M. is grateful to Fundación Paraguaya because this foundation has allowed her to be a part of this program that has taught her so much. Furthermore, she feels very proud to be a part of a group of such hardworking women who are always united and who engage in investment activities. They also use some income in order to help the members who have any type of health problem.

The loan will be utilized for the purchase of merchandise such as sugar, soft drinks, noodles, charcoal, canned goods, fruits, vegetables, and chipa ingredients like vegetable oil, eggs, milk, starch, among other goods.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer.

El comité está compuesto por 17 señoras trabajadoras del barrio Conavi de la ciudad de Caacupé, todas son pequeñas comerciantes, actualmente el grupo se encuentra en el 4 ciclo del programa de comité de Mujeres Emprendoras, y las misma están siendo beneficiadas con un crédito promedio de G. 635.000 cada integrante.

El comité se inició gracias a la capacidad de liderazgo de la señora María S., quién se enteró que la Fundación Paraguaya posee un programa destinado exclusivamente para mujeres trabajadoras; realizo la invitación a sus demás colegas y vecinas, y así surgió el grupo llamado Renacer.

Las señoras poseen distintos tipos de negocios, entre ellos: despensas, venta de bebidas, elaboración y venta de chipas, kioscos y ventas de plantas.

El comité actualmente tiene proyectado realizar actividades de limpieza de veredas, terrenos baldíos, así también están llevando a cabo un proyecto de mejoramiento de la plaza y cancha de fútbol del barrio, para que los niños tengan un lugar sano para recrearse.

La señora Carolina, agradece a la Fundación Paraguaya porque le permitió ser parte de este programa dónde ella aprendió mucho, además se siente muy orgullosa de ser parte de un grupo de señoras muy trabajadoras que siempre están unidas y cada semana realizan actividades con la finalidad de ir capitalizando su ahorro, como así también los ingresos que son utilizados para ayudar a las integrantes que tengan algún tipo de problemas de salud.

El crédito será utilizado para la compra de mercaderías como azúcar, gaseosas, jugos, fideos, carbón, productos enlatados, verduras, frutas, etc. e ingredientes para la elaboración de las chipas como aceite vegetal, huevos, leche, almidón, entre otros.

loans.use: Purchase of sugar, soft drinks, juice, noodles, charcoal, canned goods, fruits, vegetables, vegetable oil, eggs, milk, starch, etc.

loans.name: Kuña Aty Group

texts.es:
This is a committee of 15 working women in the San Francisco Neighborhood in the city of Caacupe. Most of them make and sell “chipas,” and others have little kiosks or small stores. Currently, they are in the 8th cycle of the committee program of Women Entrepreneurs, and they are being benefited by a credit of 1,000,000 Gs the equivalent of 217 dollars for each member.

The committee started with the initial reunions of Mrs. Felicita L., who was in charge of gathering the women to be members. Two of the many characteristics of this group is their punctuality in their payments and their savings.

This committee is part of a group of 3 committees of Women Entrepreneurs that gathered under the supervision of the Caacupe office of Paraguayan Foundation, with the objective of cleaning abandoned lots, the streets and alleys in their neighborhood, on order to stop the breeding of mosquitoes. There are many infectious diseases transmitted by these insects.

The women are soliciting this credit to invest in their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Escalante Kiva volunteer

El comité está compuesto por 15 señoras trabajadoras del barrio San Francisco de la ciudad de Caacupé, la mayoría se dedica a la elaboración y venta de chipas, otras poseen despensas y kioscos. Actualmente el grupo se encuentra en el 8 ciclo del programa de comité de Mujeres Emprendoras, y la misma están siendo beneficiadas con un crédito promedio de G. 1.000.000 cada integrante.

El comité se inició con las primeras reuniones en la casa de la señora Felicita López, quién fue la encargada de convocar a las señoras. Una de las características del grupo es la puntualidad en el pago de sus cuotas y sus ahorros.

El comité actualmente es parte integrante de un grupo de 3 comités de Mujeres Emprendedoras que se unieron bajo la supervisión de la oficina de Caacupé de la Fundación Paraguaya, con el fin realizar limpieza de patios baldíos, veredas, calles de sus barrios con la finalidad de eliminar criaderos de mosquitos ya que existen diversas enfermedades que se transmiten con la picadura de estos insectos.

Las señoras solicitan el crédito para invertirlos en sus negocios.

loans.use: Para la compra de almidón, queso, aceite vegetal, así azùcar, carne, yerba, harina, leche, carbón, y bebidas de todo tipo.

loans.name: Maria Nicolasa

texts.es:
Mrs. Maria Nicolasa R. dedicates herself to the sale of cosmetics and merchandise in general. The way in which she displays her products is partly from visits that she makes to her neighbors or businesses, and also in her home. She works by request, since the products that she sells are from catalogs. She has been in this business for 8 years, and due to the time invested in it, she has been able to form her own inventory and she has it at her disposal in her house. Mrs Maria is married and has 2 children that are in primary school. Her husband is a taxi driver. Due to the type of work her husband does the income of the family can be varied and because of this Mrs. Maria tries to sell the best quantity of products to help on the days in which her husband brings little money home. Her aspirations are to continue with the business of catalog sales and with the earnings she will be able to put a small store in her home to sell cosmetics and various products. She will use the money to purchase the products that her clients order.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Maria Nicolasa R. se dedica a la venta de cosméticos y mercadería en general. La forma de colocar sus productos es por medio de visitas que ella hace a sus vecinos o empresas, y también atiende en su casa de habitación. Trabaja por medio de encargos, ya que los productos que vende son de catálogos. Tiene 8 años en este negocio, y debido al tiempo invertido en él, es como ella ha podido formar su propio inventario y los tiene a disposición en su casa. Doña Maria es casada y tiene 2 hijos, que están cursando la educación primaria. Su esposo es conductor de taxi. Debido al tipo de trabajo de su marido el ingreso de la familia suele ser variado es por eso que doña Maria trata de vener la mayor cantidad de productos para solventar los días en que su esposo lleva muy poco dinero a la familia. Sus aspiraciones son seguir en el negocio de las ventas por catálogos y con las ganacias de éste poder llegar a poner una pequeña tienda en su casa de habitación de venta de cosméticosy productos varios. el dineró lo usará en las compras de los productos que le encargan sus clientes.

loans.use: To purchase cosmetics and purfumes

loans.name: Maria Lourdes

texts.es:
Mrs. Maria Lourdes is 49 years old and married. She lives in Iietapa of the Hialeth neighborhood of Managua. Her husband is an electrical engineer and he works in a state business. Mrs. Maria Lourdes dedicates herself to the sale of clothes, shoes and electrical appliances. Due to the little income of this pair, Maria Lourdes saw the necessity to sell food on the weekend, she sells beef soup, small businesses have helped her to succeed and to have a comfortable life with her family. The school time is about to begin and she will use the loan to purchase tools and school uniforms to distribute to her clients and neighbors.

Translated from Spanish by Fallon Shields, Kiva Volunteer.

Doña Maria Lourdes tiene 49 años de edad, es casada. Habita en la Iietapa del barrio Hialeah de Managua. Su esposo es Ingeniero Electronico y trabaja en una empresa estatal. Doña Maria Lourdes se deica a la venta de ropa, zapatos, electrodomesticos. Debido a los pocos ingresos por parte de esta pareja, Maria Lourdes se vió en la necesidad de vender comida los fines de semanas, ella vende sopa de res y Baho, estos pequeños negocios le han ayudado a salir adelante y llevar una vida cómoda junto a su familia. La época escolar está por empezar y ocupará el préstamo en la compra e útiles y uniformes escolares para distriburilos entre sus clientes y vecinos del barrio donde habita.

loans.use: The purchase of tools and school uniforms.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Continue diversifying his inventory
